artcl_ctt:
? When you look at the figures... Asian economies are on the rebound.
But then... there ARE aspects of life... that''ll take longer to return to where they were... before the crisis.
Arirang Oh Jiwon covered an international conference in Korea... on something more personal than the numbers... the impact on the family.

? Just two years ago, once-thriving Asian economies took a nosedive.
Companies went bankrupt, regional currencies took a tumble... while hundreds of thousands of workers lost their jobs. 
Suddenly, many were without means to support themselves or their families.
? "So many more people have become poorer.
Those who were starting to just get a little bit of a breather were being pulled back again.
Only slowly are some of them been able to get out of it, but it''s going to be a long process."
And caught up in the economic quagmire are the children.
Developing Asian economies are reporting a growing number of kids who are suffering from malnutrition.
That''s alarming... in that a whole generation of children may be impaired in their physical and intellectual development.
? "Although signs of a gradual economic recovery are evident throughout the region, experts say the social reprecussions from the crisis will take much longer to reverse."
Poverty is on the rise... while middle class living standards are on a sharp decline.
?"There has been a serious degree of family breakups in Korea.
There have been many instances of parents leaving their children, and couples divorcing or living separately under forced circumstances."
Participants are calling for stronger social safety nets, more job opportunities, and education assistance for children of low-income families.
According to the panelists, the financial crisis has brought on hardships to many people in Asia... but the crisis has also brought to the forefront, the importance of families as a fundamental social unit... that serves as the  backbone to a nation''s welfare and development.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV for CNN World Report.?

?While there are definite signs of a recovering economy... the truth is... there are also people struggling to make ends meet in Korea.
Well... reporter Oh JiWon has the story about a community service program... that''s making a difference this holiday season.
And it''s about sharing one of life''s most basic needs.

? The Food Bank system operates on a simple principle... reduce hunger by reducing waste.
Businesses donate excess fruits, vegetables, canned goods and other food stuff to local food bank chapters.
Volunteers either pick up the food or connect the donor with families or organizations in need.
? "There are many needy people ever since the IMF crisis.
We are glad to give what little we can to help the homeless, the elderly and orphanges."?
The food bank accepts slightly damaged grocery goods... like dented cans... items that won''t sell but are still too good to throw away.
Most of the time, donations are surplus products that retailers would have returned to their suppliers.
?"This is keeping good food from going to waste.
It also clears unwanted merchandise from store shelves and reduces disposal costs.
In all, it''s a win-win situation for everyone involved."?
Contributions are tax deductible and needless to say, the food is appreciated by many in the community.
The food bank network enables organizations to stretch their limited resources.
?"The donations really help the mothers.
The condiments go a long way in preparing side dishes."
That means other necessities like clothing and medicine can be purchased with the grocery money that is saved.
?  "This is more than simply giving handouts.
Those on the receiving end know there are people who care.
And that fosters a sense of unity."?	
?
According to Mr. Choi, who oversees the food bank program in Seoul, requests for emergency food are higher than ever but donations, unfortunately, lag behind.?

So on a day like this, volunteers from day care centers, nursing homes, and half-way houses are more than happy to load heavy boxes of donated goods.
They all agree it''s the spirit of sharing that helps them through the tough times.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV for CNN World Report.?

? In the famine-strickened North... eggs are considered a luxury.
On the other hand... here in the South... there''s an overflow of eggs this year... sending the prices plummeting.
So what''s being done about this?
Arirang TV has more.

?Some vivid images of malnourished children in North Korea.
As reports of starvation keep leaking out of the Stalinist country... continued efforts are underway in the South to lend a helping hand.
The latest donation drive... involves a type of food many here would consider ordinary... but which... north of the DMZ... under the present circumstances... is a luxury.
?? "Due to the over-production of eggs, farmers are facing difficulty as prices have plummeted."
So... in a classic case of supply and demand... a Seoul-based civic group saw the solution.
It''s called the 20-million egg campaign... sponsored by the Korean Sharing Movement... along with the Livestock Cooperatives Federation.
It''s aimed at feeding North Koreans... while helping egg farmers in South Korea.
?? "One egg for one person... that''s the idea.
A total of 20-million eggs will go to North Korea... with the first shipment being made on Christmas."
As the Korean Sharing Movement puts it... the egg donation is a good example of how their work can benefit the two Koreas.
??  "In the future, our efforts should be geared toward helping the North understand the fundamentals to boost its agricultural productivity."
 The North''s food situation is said to have improved... with international food aid pouring in.
Nonetheless, the U-N''s World Food Program says North Korea will need at least 1-point-3 million tons of food aid this year to get by.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: Eggs to North Korea for CNN World Report
artcl_titl_en: Eggs to North Korea for CNN World Report

artcl_ctt:
? Christians and Catholics across the nation celebrated the birth of Jesus Christ today by attending Mass and Services.... 
? At Korea''s largest Roman Catholic Church in Myungdong, downtown Seoul.... Archbishop Chung Jin-Suk(정진석).... appealed to people to spread Christ''s message of love and forgiveness....and think especially of those in need.
In other Churches..... Christian leaders delivered similar messages of hope and salvation.
Meanwhile.....in Bethlehem....thousands of Christian pilgrams flocked to the town where Jesus was born to begin millennium Christian festivities...despite the U-S global terrorism warning.
Also in Vatican....tens of thousands of people are expected to gather at Saint Peter''s Square....to witness Pope John Paul the Second open the Vatican''s millennium celebrations.?

artcl_titl: 대한항공 화물기 추락, 계기 오작동 확인
artcl_titl_en: 대한항공 화물기 추락, 계기 오작동 확인

artcl_ctt:
? The two Koreas met in Seoul for a series of basketball friendlies... a follow-up to a September match-up in Pyongyang... making history as this century''s last sports exchange between the rival Koreas.
Arirang TV has more.

? For the first time in nine-years... the two Koreas met face-to-face in Seoul... putting aside their different ideolgies for the sake of sportsmanship.
The event comes amid better economic ties between the rival Koreas... with the South''s largest conglomerate Hyundai spearheading the way for greater exchanges.
In the first of the two-day basketball friendlies... North and South Korean athletes got a chance to know each other better... regrouped into mixed teams.
Then... 
??"After a day mixing players... it''s basketball showdown... South Korea versus North Korea. 
There may be a chill running across the 38th parellel on the Korean peninsula... but the mood is quite contrary here in Chamsil Olympic Gymnasium... jubilation and excitement... with 12-thousand spectators rooting for both sides."
One definite star... was Ri Myung-hoon... the world''s tallest player... looking almighty in all his 7-foot-9... or 2-point-35-meters height.
Ri proved he not only outstood others in size but skill... While the older generation stressed the significance of the games... 
?? "We''ve always wanted to see unification through sports exchanges... I can''t believe it''s happening today."
Most of the younger crowds said it just felt great.
? (Great.)
?  (Great.)
And... regardless of whose side they were on... 
?	 "I want the North to take home a victory."
?
 "Unfortunately, you''ve got to have one winner. Of course, South Korea."
?
 "I want it to be an even tie."
The excitement was evident.
The final score came down to an even tie... with the South winning in the women''s division... while the North took the victory in the men''s game.
The game of hoops... dubbed "reunification matches" gave rise to hopes such exchanges will ease tensions between Seoul and Pyongyang.
Two countries that are still ideological foes but friends in the arena of sports.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: Inter-Korean Basketball for CNN World Report
artcl_titl_en: Inter-Korean Basketball for CNN World Report

artcl_ctt: ? Hello everyone ... hope all of you are enjoying a Merry Christmas as we welcome you to Arirang News.?

? That''s all for now .... join us again later tonight for a final wrap up of the day''s top stories.
Thanks for being with us.?

? Parts of Korea''s south are enjoying a White Christmas today... the first in ten years.
The regions include... North and South Cholla provinces... where a heavy snow warning is still issued at this hour.
As much as eight centimeters of snow was recorded over Christmas eve... with another four centimeters expected before the day is over.
Road conditions are less than favorable in the south... forcing authorities to close some roads along the mountainside.
For those planning to be out and about today... authorities are urging people to put on snow tires.?
? Good evening everyone ... hope all of you are enjoying a merry Christmas in the company of loved ones.?

? That''s our report for this Saturday .... thanks for being with us.
From all of us here at Arirang TV ... take care and good night.?

?In Chechnya.... Russian forces besieged the capital Grozny.? 
Russian tanks started advancing from several directions under the cover of thick smoke.
The move follows heavy shelling overnight.
The Russian military has denied the latest attacks are the start of a decisive storm but... military officials have advised the 30 thousand civilians still trapped within the city... to stay put as the city will be under Russian control within a few days.?
artcl_titl: 러시아군, 체첸 그로즈니 도심 진격#Russian Army Advances into Grozny#
artcl_titl_en: 러시아군, 체첸 그로즈니 도심 진격#Russian Army Advances into Grozny#

artcl_ctt:
? Seoul''s night will get brighter starting the new milliennium.
This... because all the national treasures around the city... as well as buildings 21 stories plus will be equipped with lights... to illuminate the city.
And to prepare for the new year... next week... the Seoul government plans to light all the street lamps.
Since the economic crisis erupted in the winter of 1997... the city has been using only half of the lamps. ?

anc_ment_ctt:
?@ And the latest on North Korea's controversial plan to launch a rocket...
The South Korean government... citing recent satellite images says Pyongyang's three-stage rocket has been dismantled from the launch pad.
Choi You-sun (최유선) reports.
artcl_ctt:
?@ According to the most recent satellite images, North Korea has dismantled its three-stage rocket on the ?@launch pad at the country's northwestern launch site.
Officials in Seoul say the rocket's technical defect is likely something that can not be resolved when it's standing, but that the North seems determined to fire it nonetheless.
On Monday, Pyongyang extended the launch window to December 29th, saying there was a problem in the first stage control engine module of the rocket.
Diplomacy amongst six-party talk members to stop the North's cover-up for a ballistic missile test continues.
?@ Wang Jiarui, the international department director of the Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee, is scheduled to meet U.S. Deputy Secretary of State William Burns in Washington on Tuesday.
U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton spoke about preventing another North Korean provocation during a recent phone conversation with her Chinese counterpart Yang Jiechi.

?@?@ "The question was what influence China could bring to bear on the DPRK to see reason and focus on the development of their country and the feeding of people rather than on ballistic missile launches that are in violation of their international obligations."

Russia's top nuclear envoy is scheduled to visit Seoul on Wednesday and South Korea's Deputy Minister for Multilateral and Global Affairs Kim Bong-hyun will travel to Beijing next Monday to discuss the two sides' cooperation at the UN Security Council.
?@ In a statement, the foreign ministers of the 27-member European Union warned there would be a clear response from the international community if the North fires another rocket, following a failed attempt in April.
Choi You-sun, Arirang News.?@
artcl_titl: (18)"北 장거리로켓 발사대에서 내려 내부수리중"#Satellite Imagery Shows N. Korea Likely Dismantled 3-stage Rocket#
artcl_titl_en: (18)"北 장거리로켓 발사대에서 내려 내부수리중"#Satellite Imagery Shows N. Korea Likely Dismantled 3-stage Rocket#

artcl_ctt:
The year 1999 marked the passing of a wide spectrum of people who left their marks on the world, and who in some cases affected the way the world perceives itself --its aspirations, fears and dreams. 

Athletics saw several stars and icons pass. Some like  American football great Walter Payton, golfer Payne Stewart and cricket star Malcolm Marshall died relatively young. Others, like basketball player Wilt Chamberlain, seemed larger than life. And there were those, such as Joe DiMaggio and Pee Wee Reese, who had been lionized for decades. 

Among those who passed in the international political arena were two monarchs who played important roles in the Middle East peace process -- Hussein of Jordan and Hassan of Morocco. Africa and much of the world noted the passing of two historic figures, Julius Nyerere of Tanzania and Joshua Nkomo of Zimbabwe. There was also a reminder of Greece''s infamous military government of the 1960s and ''70s with news that former junta leader George Papadopoulos had died. 

In the United States, news of John F. Kennedy Jr.''s death stunned and saddened millions, especially those who had grown up with him and his father''s legacy. Among the others: Judith Campbell Exner, alleged mistress of the late President Kennedy, and John Ehrlichman, one of the key players in the Watergate scandal that brought down President Nixon. 

The business world noted the passing of several of its more original minds in 1999, among them Sony founder
Akio Morita, U.S. architect and industrialist Charles    Luckman, advertising maven David Ogilvy and candy  empire heir Forrest Mars Sr.

? After taking part in this century''s last inter-Korean sports exchange... the North Korean delegation headed home.
? Upon their departure... Hyundai chairman Chung Mong-hun(정몽헌) bid them farewell... saying the basketball friendlies added a great momentum in enhancing the two Koreas'' relations.
North Korea''s chief delegate Song Ho-gyong(송호경) said his Asia-Pacific Peace Committee ... would work further to strengthen exchanges not only with Hyundai but other civic groups in the future.
North Korea''s star player... Ri Myung-hoon(리명훈)... who was the center of media attention also thanked the South Korean people for their support.
The two days of goodwill games came down to an even tie... with the North winning in the men''s division... while the South took the victory in the women''s game.?
artcl_titl: 통일농구 북측 방문단 출국#North Korean Basketball Team Leaves#
artcl_titl_en: 통일농구 북측 방문단 출국#North Korean Basketball Team Leaves#

artcl_ctt:
? Economic Ministers from Korea and China will hold their first meeting Monday in Beijing.
? Kang Bong-kyun, Korea''s Finance and Economy Minister will be in China for three days, meeting with Zeng Peiyang ... Chinese Minister for State Development Planning Commission.
The two will discuss the framework of a regional cooperative body for East Asia.
The idea was proposed during last month''s trilateral summit among Korea, China and Japan.
Also Kang will ask for Korean companies to take part in the bidding for Chinese digital mobile phone industry, and reactor projects.
The two countries have held vice-ministerial economic talks before, but this is the first ministers meeting.?
artcl_titl: Korea-China # Korea and China, 1st Economic Ministers Meeting #
artcl_titl_en: Korea-China # Korea and China, 1st Economic Ministers Meeting #

artcl_ctt:
? Christians and Catholics around the world are celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ on this last Christmas of the century.
Meanwhile in Seoul... last night''s hustle and bustle created by the morning snow seem to have calmed down.
Here''s more.

? In Bethlehem....thousands of Christian pilgrams flocked to the town where Jesus was born to begin millennium Christian festivities.
While in Vatican....tens of thousands of people  gathered at Saint Peter''s Square....to witness Pope John Paul the Second open the Vatican''s millennium celebrations.
In Seoul... however, the morning after the first snow white Christmas in a decade was rather quiet.
Most of Seoul''s major streets and outbound expressways were empty contrary to yesterday''s heavy traffic which lasted well into the night.
And, the situation was no different in downtown theatres with people opting spend the holidays at home.
But, the sounds of songs and prayers kept coming out at churches and places of worship... with Christians and Catholics across the nation celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ.
At Korea''s largest Roman Catholic Church in Myungdong, downtown Seoul.... Archbishop Chung Jin-Suk(정진석).... appealed to everyone to spread Christ''s message of love and forgiveness....and think especially of those in need.?

?Turning our attention overseas... in ?early February... the world witnessed the passing of a man who meant more to his people  than just a monarch.
King Hussein of Jordan.
He grew from a boy to elder statesman... symbolizing endurance and a voice for the Middle East peace process.
On July 16th... Americans had to bid farewell to their favorite son.
John F. Kennedy Junior, his wife Carolyn and sister-in-law Lauren Bessette were killed when their plane crashed into the waters off Martha''s Vineyard.
Kennedy Junior was 38.?

? Many concerts were held around town last night to celebrate Christmas Eve, but the one featured in our next story was quite unique.
It was unique because, instead of a regular stage, it was held at a soy sauce factory.... 
Rah Seungyun reports.

? Soy sauce and rock music .... it''s not the most likely combination.
But its very unlikeliness could be the fact which drew two thousand young people to an old soy-sauce factory on the out-skirts of Seoul on Christmas Eve.
The brainchild of two old friends... the Seng Seng Variety Show... meaning Fresh Variety Show... is an attempt to bring the old, closer to the new.
The old in this case, is the Sempyo Soy Sauce company.
The company is planning to move its operations to another location, and in commemoration, decided to throw a party for the young.
?? "Our company is fifty years old, and is very well-known to the older generation.  We decided to offer a playground for youngsters to have fun in their own terms, we can come close to the younger generation."
It wouldn''t have been so easy, without the help of a super-hip, young brand... called Ssamzie.
??	Sempyo conjures up our grandmother''s cooking, our traditional taste.  And it''s something that Ssamzie, which is only about 15 years old, has grown up on."
Park and the president of the leather goods store are school buddies, and when they were reunited last summer after three decades.... they decided to create a new, unique cultural scene.
?This concert is their second joint project... they had held another concert at a local university this past fall.
?The main purpose of these events may just be a marketing strategy... trying to approach tomorrow''s consumers on their grounds... but for those enjoying the concert .... it really doesn''t seem to matter all that much.
Rah Seungyun, Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: Sempyo Rock Concert # Sempyo X-mas Concert #
artcl_titl_en: Sempyo Rock Concert # Sempyo X-mas Concert #

artcl_ctt:
? Ruling and opposition party heads are likely to meet on Thursday, December 30th.
Political sources say the ruling National Congress ?for New Politics and the opposition Grand National Party have agreed in principle to hold the meeting before the year''s end.
President Kim Dae-jung expressed a strong will to meet with opposition leader Lee Hoi-chang to solve "all the homework" and make a fresh start along with the people next year.
G-N-P sources say Lee is ready to accept the dialogue proposal.
Meanwhile, a package deal is being negotiated between the rival camps on the parliamentary inspection of the alleged press control scandal and revisions to the election law for rezoning electoral districts.?
artcl_titl: Party Leaders'' Meeting#Party Leaders'' Meeting may be held on 30th#
artcl_titl_en: Party Leaders'' Meeting#Party Leaders'' Meeting may be held on 30th#

artcl_ctt: ? and finally let''s take a look at tomorrow''s weather for Korea and cities around the world.?

? Another Korean ace will stand on the mound of the U-S Major League.
? After trying for two years... Lee Sang-hoon(이상훈)... a left hander currently playing in Japan... has fulfilled his dream... and signed a contract with the Boston Redsox.
Under the 5-point-3 million dollar deal... Lee will be pitching for the Redsox... for three years... starting the coming season.
Lee will leave for the U-S next month... to join the team''s camp training in February.?
artcl_titl: 이상훈 ML 진출#Korean pitcher goes to ML#
artcl_titl_en: 이상훈 ML 진출#Korean pitcher goes to ML#

artcl_ctt:
? Good Morning and welcome to Arirang News on this Christmas morning.
Mostly clear skies are expected today around Korea... with highs ranging from minus three to eight degrees Celsius.
As for the temperatures this morning... they''re between minus seven and five degrees.
Seoul is reading a minus four right now.?

? And those are the stories this morning, Christmas Day, 19-99.
Thank you for watching... and we wish you happy and safe holidays!?

? Merry Christmas and welcome to Arirang Newsroom update.

We begin today with... a tense standoff in the United Arab Emirates...
Hijackers have forced an Indian Airlines'' plane to land at a military airbase in Abu Dhabi.
189-people are reportedly on board.
According to Indian officials... the unidentified hijackers have told the pilot they''ve killed four people on the plane... and wounded five more.
The hijackers are demanding fuel, food, water and medical supplies.
In return, they''re promising to release women, children and the injured.
The Indian Airlines'' jumbo jet left Nepal and was en route to India... when the hijackers took control.

Meantime... parts of Korea''s south are enjoying a White Christmas today... for the first time in ten years.
The regions include... North and South Cholla provinces... where a heavy snow warning is still issued at this hour.
As much as eight centimeters of snow was recorded over Christmas eve... with another four centimeters expected before the day is over.
Road conditions are less than favorable in around the peninsula... in particular in the eastern Kangwon province... where roads have iced over after getting 15 centimeters of snow.
For those planning to be out and about today... authorities are urging people to put on snow tires.

And finally around the world... Christians and Catholics are celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ...
Thousands of Christian pilgrams made their annual journey to Bethlehem... where Jesus was born.
And in the Vatican City... tens of thousands of people gathered in Saint Peter''s Square... to hear the millennium message from Pope John Paul the Second.
In Korea... people since last night are attending various services...
The main mass in Seoul was held at the nation''s largest Roman Catholic Church in Myungdong...
Archbishop Chung Jin-Suk(정진석)... urged people to spread Jesus Christ''s message of love and forgiveness and remember to help those people in need.

Those are the morning''s top stories.
Thank you for watching and once again... we wish you Merry Christmas!?

? On this Christmas Day... President Kim Dae-jung and the First Lady Lee Hee-ho(이희호) ?attended a special charity show hosted by the Korean Broadcasting System.
Appearing on a program called "Love Request"... President Kim said one of his New Year''s resolutions was to lead Korea into a society of caring and hope.
Kim added he would try his best to enhance the living standards of people in the lower income bracket... by reducing the gap between the rich and poor.?
artcl_titl: 김대통령 내외 자선모금행사 참석#President Kim Attends X-Mas Charity#
artcl_titl_en: 김대통령 내외 자선모금행사 참석#President Kim Attends X-Mas Charity#

artcl_ctt:
1.My mother always said if I get married and raise a family of my own... I would only be able to spend the rest of my life for the few people in the family. But by becoming a reverend mother, I can go out into the world to help and work for many more people. My mother always prayed for me to walk into this path of life.

2.By now, I have learned the priorities in life and work. I know what is most important and I also know what has to be done first. I can always sense and spot where help is needed. This is the kind of work I wish to continue as long as I can. And with the help of these warm hearted people... I know I can go on to spread love everywhere.

? Overnight in New York... the NASDAQ index broke through the four-thousand mark... for the first time ever.
? The record comes less than two months after it broke the three thousand barrier.
The tech-heavy index rocketed more than 64 points in early afternoon trading... to hit four-thousand and one-point-six-three.
It retreated to finish just under four thousand.
With the latest rally... NASDAQ is now up by 82 percent... for the year.
The market opened in 19-71... and most of the issues traded on the NASDAQ are related to computer and the Internet.?

? As always... it''s time for a quick read through the local papers...

? First off, only a week left until 19-99 gives way to the year 2000.
This has governments and businesses all over the world on alert... worried about the millennium computer bug.
In Korea, some 370-thousand public servants will be on special duty, from the 30th through January 4th... to cope with possible Y-2-K problems.

And next year... we can expect more cloned cows... three hundred more to be precise.
Yongrong-yi (영롱이) and Jinny (진이) were brought to life this year with 100 percent Korean genetic engineering technology.
They''ll be the proud parents.

The snowfall has added to the festive Christmas  spirit this year... but there are those who are not so happy.
A local mobile phone company promised to give cars to 110-people if it snows more than 1-centimeter on Christmas eve.
The company is insured for the "weather marketing ploy"... and now it seems the insurance firm... will have to dole out millions of won for the car prizes.

And we begin our newcast this morning with a look back at last night''s high spirits...?

? A tense standoff in the United Arab Emirates...
? Hijackers have forced the landing of an Indian Airlines plane at a military airbase in Abu Dhabi.
The A-300 Airbus has 189-people on board.
It made stops in India and Pakistan before touching down in the U-A-E.
The unidentified hijackers have told the pilot they''ve killed four people on the plane... and wounded five more... according to Indian officials.
The hijackers are demanding fuel, food, water and medical supplies.
In return, they''re promising to release women, children and the injured.?

? Turning to the latest on the Indian Airlines passenger plane.. hijacked on Christmas Eve.
The aircraft is currently in Afganistan and at least one person is confirmed dead.
The hijackers are reported to have asked for assylum.
The Taliban and Indian goverment, meanwhile, pledged to work closely to resolve the situation.
Here''s more.

?The hijacked plane is now in the Southern Afgan city of Kandahar.
According to a Taliban spokesman... the Indian government, which does not recognize the ruling Taliban asked that the plane be allowed to land in Afganistan after officials there intially refused the hijackers request to land there.  
Indian Airlines Flight 8-1-4 was on its way from Nepal en route to New Dehli late friday before being hijacked by 5 heavily armed men.
After making a couple of stops in India and Pakistan... the hijackers directed the plane to land in the United Arab Emrites.
While in the UAE... 25 of the 189 passengers had been released.
And body of man that had been reportedly stabbed to death was removed.
The hijackers say they have killed four.. but those deaths have not been confirmed.
The identity of the hijackers is not yet known but officials from the UAE said the hijackers were Sikhs.
Militant Sikhs whose religion is both Islam and Hinduism, have periodically waged violent campaigns gainst the Indian goverment in the last two decades.?

?In Chechnya.... Russian forces besieged the capital Grozny.? 
Russian tanks started advancing from several directions under the cover of thick smoke.
The move follows heavy shelling overnight.
The Russian military has denied the latest attacks are the start of a decisive storm but... military officials have advised the 30 thousand civilians still trapped within the city... to stay put as the city will be under Russian control within a few days.?
artcl_titl: 러시안군, 체첸 그로즈니 도심 진격#Russian Army Advances into Grozny#
artcl_titl_en: 러시안군, 체첸 그로즈니 도심 진격#Russian Army Advances into Grozny#

artcl_ctt:
? World-famous violinist... Sarah Chang just wrapped up her latest concert in Berlin, Germany.
? The 18 year old artist, hailing from Korea... wowed her fans... with her interpretation of Richard Strauss.
Under the baton of London Philharmonic''s Chief conductor... Chang played a violin concerto by Strauss... notorious for being complex.
Chang is due in Korea next week for the Seoul Millennium Concert... scheduled for the 31st at the Seoul Arts Center.
The evening will last for two and half hours and will also feature Korea''s highly acclaimed maestro Chung Myung-hoon... as well as leading local vocalists.?
artcl_titl: 장영주 연주회 독일서 찬사#Chang''s concert in Berlin#
artcl_titl_en: 장영주 연주회 독일서 찬사#Chang''s concert in Berlin#

artcl_ctt:
? Hope your Christmas eve Friday is going well.
Here are our top stories this morning...

? A white Christmas may not be in the forecast for the peninsula... but it is enjoying a white Christmas eve.

? Meantime... North and South Korean basketball players hit the court today... to wrap up the century''s last inter-Korean sports exchanges.

? And... the Seoul government is undo the greenbelts around the country... with the first lifting scheduled for next week.?

Boosted by the record bull runs in New York... Korean stocks opened higher today...
It''s jumped 17 points... to regain 990.
As for the won... though... it''s lost ground against the dollar... by some two won... to drop to 11-32 and a half.

Those are the stories at this hour.
We thank you as always for watching... and wish you all... happy holidays!?

artcl_ctt:
? The government will be injecting public funds into six of the nation''s life insurers.
Under the plan almost two-trillion won will go to clean up debts at the insurers... before the year is out.
Here''s more on the reasons behind the capital injection.

? The ultimate goal is to have healthier life insurers absorb their weaker counterparts.
But before they''re sold off... the government is stepping in to help clean up some debts.
The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today it will inject ? 1-point-9 trillion won in public money... into six troubled insurers.
That''s 1-point-6 billion in dollars... which is still 40 billion won short of the total debts held by the companies as a group.
? More than half of the total sum... will go to Dongah Life... followed by Kookmin and Doowon.
According to a KDIC official... 80 percent of the money will be injected into the insurers by the end of next week... and the rest will be doled out after further evaluation of the companies'' finances.?
The latest injection follows a similar move last month... through which 1-point-8 trillion won flowed into the six companies... each getting 30 billion.
Doowon has already been taken over by Korea Life.
And negotiations are underway for other acquisitions... including Kookmin by New York Life.?

artcl_ctt:
? A revised tariff quota system will take effect from January 1st of next year.
? The Finance and Economy Ministry says nine new items... including hot coil, pulp, and quartz glass... will be added onto the list of the revised system.
The quota on hot coil... will be reduced to three percent... from the current four to eight percent.
As for other items... partial changes were made to the tariff rates... in a bid to reflect the government''s plan to ensure a steady supply of goods.
Meanwhile... 13 items will be removed from the list... bringing down the number of items subject to the tariff quota system... to 54... in the first half of next year.?

artcl_ctt:
?In other news.
Korean stocks... boosted by an overnight rally on Wall Street... recorded their third straight day of gains today.
? The benchmark index rising 17-points to finish this last trading day of the week at 992.
Foreign investors continued their buying spree for day six... and sent the KOSPI over the thousand mark at one point during trading.
Telecom shares led the gainers today.
A total of 255 million shares traded hands on turnover of 3-point-6-5 trillion won.
As for the Korean currency... it weakened about one won from Thursday... to close the week at 11-hundred-32 won flat.?

? Most major markets across the Asia-Pacific remained in positive territory this Christmas eve.

? In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 rose on the back of Internet related shares.
The benchmark index ended 123-points higher at 18-thousand-585.
Softbank... one of the world''s largest Internet companies rose nearly 7-percent... boosted by Nasdaq''s overnight gains.
Some analysts predict the Nikkei has room to move further up... before the year is out.?

artcl_titl_en: 유가족, 신원 확인 위해 영국 출발

artcl_ctt:
?Well... ? Seoul today got five centimeters of  snowfall... with 1995 being the last time it snowed in the capital on Christmas Eve.
A heavy snow alert was in effect for Seoul and the surrounding Kyonggi area... from six in the morning to one-thirty in the afternoon.
As for other regions... Hongchun in Kangwon Province received the most snow... at close to eleven centimeters.
The weather condition made travelling on the roads difficult... and forecasters say drivers will have to be extra cautious tomorrow... as the roads will likely ice over... with temperatures expected to drop tonight.?

?East Asia''s tourism business is regaining its former strength... on the recent economic recovery.
And its momentum is expected to grow even more... with travellers catching millennium fever.

? Double digit growth in the number of tourists in East Asian countries... led the world''s booming tourism industry this year.
The Korea National Tourism Organization says... the number of tourists worldwide was an estimated 665-million... up five percent from last year.
?By country... Taiwan topped the list... with a 15-point-6 percent surge in the number of foreign visitors... followed by China... with 15-point-5 percent.
Hong Kong''s tourism industry enjoyed a 13-percent rise... while this country saw a jump of more than 10 percent.?
Citing figures released by the World Tourism Organization... K-N-T-O says... the global surge is in line with the recent economic recovery in the region.
And with the millennium fever running high... experts say fears over Y-2-K problems pose little threat to the industry''s growth. 
The state-run tourism agency paints an even rosier outlook for the new millennium.
Kim Kiho, Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: 동북아, 세계 관광시장 성장 주도#East Asia Led World Tourism Industry#
artcl_titl_en: 동북아, 세계 관광시장 성장 주도#East Asia Led World Tourism Industry#

artcl_ctt:
? And... here''s a look at how some young Koreans spent Christmas Eve, last night.
? They checked out a rock concert... put on by underground musicians... inside a soy sauce factory.
It''s literally a case of INDUSTRIAL ROCK... the idea coming from the Saempyo soy sauce company... and Ssamzie... a fashion brand.
The presidents of these two firms are high school buddies... and say they wanted to create an item popular among young people.
About 2-thousand fans attended the concert.
On stage were big Korean underground names... like Crying Nut... the Hwang Shinhye Band... and Nero(네로).?
artcl_titl: 간장ROCK(22BA)#Underground rockers hold concert in soy sauce factory#
artcl_titl_en: 간장ROCK(22BA)#Underground rockers hold concert in soy sauce factory#

artcl_ctt:
? In the headlines this Friday...

? Snow across the country... on this Christmas Eve...

? The government pledges two-trillion won... to clean up debts at ailing life insurers...

? And basketball players from the two Koreas face off on the courts... for the last inter-Korean friendly matches of the century.?

? Meanwhile in Hong Kong...
Despite a shortened holiday session... the Hang Seng surged 3-percent to 16-thousand-833.
That is a new record close since August.
HSBC Holdings... Hutchinson Whampoa and other heavyweights fueled the rally today.

Over in Singapore... the Straits Times advanced 9-tenths of a percent to a record high of 24-46.
Tech shares dominated the market... boosted by Nasdaq''s solid performance. 

And shares in Sydney finished in the black as well.
The All Ordinaries rose almost 18-points to end trading at 31-35.
News Corp... the world''s fourth largest media company led the gainers in the land down under.
Meanwhile... the index is up 11-percent this year... on its way to a fifth consecutive year of gains.

We''ll now turn to how the Korean won fared against other regional currencies.?

?Hope your day''s going well.
Hello and welcome to this week''s final edition of Biz Today.
?

anc_ment_ctt:
?@ Imagine leaving your ever-expanding wallet at home... and still having the convenience of using your credit cards, coupons, and membership card...
Sound too good to be true?
Well, one of Korea's biggest wireless carriers wants to lighten your load by making smartphones your new wallets.
Paul Yi has more.
artcl_ctt:
?@ Savvy consumers these days are saying goodbye to paper and plastic, in favor of their smartphones.
Here at this coffee shop, customers are able to pay for drinks, redeem digital coupons, and keep track of membership points all from one mobile device.
This example of converging technologies and services has become a booming trend in Korea, which is providing high convenience for customers and businesses alike.

(Korean)
?@?@?@ "I didn't like that my wallet was thick due to cards, receipts, and coupons. Now my wallet is thin and it's nice that I can comfortably use my smartphone."

Korea's leading corporations are racing to ensure smartphones not only compliment cash and credit, but eventually consolidate everyone's financial needs through a single mobile application.

Earlier this month, Korea's second largest cell phone carrier, KT Telecom announced a new instant mobile payment system called Mo-Ca, a combination of the words "money" and "card." 

The MoCa Alliance has already brought on board over 60 companies including the country's leading banking institutions, coffee shop chains, and department stores. 

(Korean)
?@?@?@"Credit cards, coupons, and a wide range of mobile gift certificates will all be available on cell phones. It's a service that aims to simplify everything for the customer."

The new system is said to be 90 percent faster than other popular payment methods and much more secure than competing solutions such as Google Wallet.

(Korean)
?@ ?@	?@
"There's no need to store any financial information on the cell phone because it doesn't go through the merchant. This way there are no leaks or risks of exposing financial information. "

?@The MoCa smartphone app is now available to download and use, but consumers shouldn't completely ditch their cash and credit just yet.

Paul Yi, Arirang News?@
artcl_titl: (SAVE)스마트폰, '만능 카드'로 변신#New Mobile Payment System Aims to Replace Wallets#
artcl_titl_en: (SAVE)스마트폰, '만능 카드'로 변신#New Mobile Payment System Aims to Replace Wallets#

artcl_ctt:
? The prosecution has sought an arrest warrant for the chairman of the ShinDongBang (신동방) Group.
? Chairman Shin Myung-soo (신명수) is being charged with violating stock transaction laws and sending money abroad illegally.
According to prosecutors... Shin submitted bogus financial records... when his company issued new shares in January.
Investors suffered huge losses... as a result.
Shin is also charged with manipulating the price of his company shares... and pocketing four billion won.
As for the illegal transfer of funds... he allegedly wired 85-billion won... by setting up a ghost company in Malaysia.
Shin is the in-law of former President Roh Tae-woo.
Another case involving Shin is also currently pending.
He was previously investigated... for managing ex-President Roh''s slush fund back in 1995.?
artcl_titl: 검찰, 신명수 영장 청구 방침#Arrest warrant for ShinDongBang chair#

artcl_ctt:
? The Korean chapter of Habitat for Humanity has been building homes for the underprivileged, since it was founded four years ago.
In the capital... its first project... a five story building... broke ground back in July...
And... now, after five months of hard work round the clock... the unit is complete... and helping to make this an unforgettable Christmas for its new tenants.
Shim Miryung has our story.

? The number of houses in Korea has doubled to 9 million in the past 20 years.
But for those without the means... owning a house can be a struggle.
It''s for these people that Habitat for Humanity Korea has been building homes for.
??"I''m so happy this Seoul Habitat house worked out, because it''s difficult to build a house in the capital.  But with the effort of 400 people, we made it..."?
The house... though... is not free.
It comes with price called sweat equity... around 500 hours of labor going into the building.
The owners also have to pay back the construction fee of 20-million won or 17-thousand U-S dollars, over a 15 year period, at no-interest.
Thirty two families applied for the Seoul Habitat home out of which five... including Kim Soo-young, were selected.
??("I want to hand over this gift from God to others in need as we were, as soon as things get better for us.") ?   
?	"I''m so happy. I want to invite my friends and have a party."
Kim... who worked 700 hours... more than the required amount, even hurt his waist... but has never felt happier.
More than four-hundred volunteers, including students and professionals also helped out.
?
 "The century''s last Christmas will be especially meaningful for the five families... whose dreams of owning their own homes have finally come true through Habitat.
Shim Miryung, Arirang TV."?

? 


After a day of mixing players... it''s basketball showdown... North Korea versus South Korea.
But... with the goodwill match being this century''s last inter-Korean sports exchange... many are hoping the game will pave the way for a mood of reconcilation on the Korean peninsula.

? Let''s turn now to some stories the local papers are talking about...

? First off... a court ruling that will change the hiring practices in Korea.
Until now, men who completed compulsory military service had gotten extra points on their admission tests... which was to the disadvantage of women and the physically disabled.
But now... the court ruling says everyone will be given equal footing... starting with tests to pick civil servants.

Restrictions in the greenbelt regions near the Shiwha(시화) Industrial Complex will be lifted next week... the first such move for the country.
This means developers will be able to build houses and other facitilites in the area.
Greenbelts were designated decades ago... to prevent over-development.

Finally, with Christmas just around the corner... the spirit of peace and love prevails... even beyond religious boundaries.
Buddhist monks at the Chogye Temple in downtown Seoul have put up a large sign celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ and wishes for a Merry Christmas.
It''s the first time the temple is showcasing such a holiday sign.

As for OUR top story this morning... a closer look at the weather and road conditions around the peninsula...?

? An additional one-point-nine trillion won in public funds... will be poured into six ailing life insurance firms by the end of this month.
? The six include... Kookmin and Dong-ah... 
All of them will be taken over by healthier life insurers.
The Deposit Insurance Corporation says the injection of funds is being made to facilitate the take-over.
The money will go towards covering the six companies'' debts which exceed their assets.?
artcl_titl: 6개 부실 생보사에 공적자금 투입#Public funds to be injected in 6 life insurers#
artcl_titl_en: 6개 부실 생보사에 공적자금 투입#Public funds to be injected in 6 life insurers#

artcl_ctt:
?

? This year''s Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to a group of medical volunteers... known in English as Doctors Without Borders.
The group dispatches some 25-hundred medical professionals every year to work in 80-countries.
They were praised by the Nobel committee for working under difficult circumstances... often putting their lives at risk... in some of the world''s most dangerous hot spots. 

Doctors Without Borders... like so many nongovernmental organizations or N-G-O''s... focuses on humanitarian rather than commercial objectives.
N-G-Os are non-profit, voluntary groups that work to benefit the welfare of the community... from small grass roots projects... to those that cover global issues... like Greenpeace and the environment or Amnesty International and human rights.

Recognizing the growing importance of NGO''s worldwide... Seoul played host to an international conference for NGO''s this October.
2000 groups from 100? countries took part in what was the first ever multi-issue NGO gathering... covering everything from gender equality... to sustainable economic growth.
It''s concerned citizens with a common goal... to create a civil society.

Oh JiWon Arirang TV.?

? Let''s turn now to some stories the local papers are talking about...

? First off... a court ruling that will change the hiring practices in Korea.
Until now, men who completed compulsory military service had gotten extra points on their admission tests... which was to the disadvantage of women and the physically disabled.
But now... the court ruling says everyone will be given equal footing... starting with tests to pick civil servants.

Restrictions in the greenbelt regions near the Shiwha(시화) Industrial Complex will be lifted next week... the first such move for the country.
This means developers will be able to build houses and other facitilites in the area.
Greenbelts were designated decades ago... to prevent over-development.

Finally, with Christmas just around the corner... the spirit of peace and love prevails... even beyond religious boundaries.
Buddhist monks at the Chogye Temple in downtown Seoul have put up a large sign celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ and wishes for a Merry Christmas.
It''s the first time the temple is showcasing such a holiday sign.

As for OUR top story this morning... a closer look at the weather and road conditions around the peninsula...?
? Now... a look at what to expect in the weather condition... in Korea and around the world.?
? Hello and welcome to this edition of Arirang News.?

? The Commerce, Industry, and Energy Ministry says... it plans to inaugurate the Korea Technology Exchange... in January, next year.
? The company is looking for executives... experienced in the Research and Development sector and commercialization of technology.
The Ministry says... qualified individuals, regardless of nationality... will be considered for the position of chief executive officer.
Applicants must submit their resumes to the ministry by January third.?
artcl_titl: CEO of Korea Tech Exchange to be Recruited
artcl_titl_en: CEO of Korea Tech Exchange to be Recruited

artcl_ctt:
? Meanwhile... cities across the United States are on heightened security alert... amid rising concerns about possible terrorist attacks over the holidays.
Extra checks are being conducted at the borders, airports... and now... the post offices.
Here''s the latest.

? Yet another statement was issued by the U-S Department of State... hightening fears of a bomb threat.
The government believes terrorists may be planning an guerilla attack against American citizens around the world during the crucial holiday season.
The U-S government issued a travel advisory warning to Americans to pay extra attention...like avoiding large crowds and gatherings...as they could be targets at home and abroad.
As a result, airports and border crossings have been under high alert since the arrest of a suspected terrorist who tried to smuggle explosives into the U-S from Canada.
The F-B-I also warned the public to be careful of any suspicious packages from overseas due to possible mail bomb threats.
The fresh announcement comes after U-S President Bill Clinton extended the warning time period by another week to mid-January.
For now... U-S authorities are refusing to disclose the source of the warning or about those who may be involved.?

?China''s exports are expected to rise five percent this year.
?From January to November of this year... exports increased 6-point-6 percent to around 175-billion dollars... while imports jumped by 21-percent... to 148-billion.
Total import and export volume reached 323 billion dollars... which is an increase of about 13-percent from last year.
Meanwhile... estimates of actual overseas investment for the whole of 19-99... is expected to surpass 38-billion dollars.
?
artcl_titl: Chinese exports rise 5 percent this year
artcl_titl_en: Chinese exports rise 5 percent this year

artcl_ctt:
? HELLO MERRY CHRISTMAS AND WELCOME TO OUR 2-MINUTE NEWSROOM UPDATE.... MAKING THE HEADLINES TODAY.

? THE CAPITAL SEOUL HAS ISSUED A HEAVY SNOW ALERT THIS MORNING. 
AUTHORITIES SAY MOST ROADS WILL REMAIN OPEN BUT SOME HILLY SECTIONS HAVE BEEN CLOSED... DUE TO SLIPPERY CONDITIONS.
THAT''S BELIEVED TO CAUSE SOME TRAFFIC CONGESTION DURING THIS MORNING''S COMMUTE.
DRIVERS HAVE BEEN WARNED TO TAKE EXTRA CARE ON THE ROADS TODAY.
SO FAR ... SEOUL HAS SEEN 4 CENTIMETERS OF SNOW... AND THE REST OF THE NATION... ANYWHERE BETWEEN ONE TO TEN CENTIMETERS.
WEATHERMEN SAY MORE SNOW OR RAIN IS IN THE FORECAST TODAY.

? MEN AND WOMEN NORTH AND SOUTH KOREAN BASKETBALL TEAMS WILL FACE OFF ON THE COURT TODAY.... THE LAST IN A SERIES OF REVIVED SPORTS EXCHANGES BETWEEN THE TWO COUNTRIES... THIS DECADE.
THE SOUTH KOREAN TEAMS ARE SEEKING TO MAKE UP FOR THEIR LOSSES DURING THE SEPTEMBER GAME HELD IN PYONYANG.
ALSO TO GAIN ATTENTION... PERFORMANCES BY PYONGYANG ACROBAT TROOPS.... AT THE BASKETBALL COURT IN CHAMSIL, SOUTHERN SEOUL.
FOLLOWING THE GAME... THE NORTH KOREAN DELEGATION SAYS IT''S SCHEDULED TO HOST A DINNER RECEPTION FOR HYUNDAI GROUP OFFICIALS AT A SEOUL HOTEL.

? OVERNIGHT IN NEW YORK... THE TECH-HEAVY NASDAQ HAS BROKEN THROUGH THE FOUR-THOUSAND POINT LEVEL FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE THE MARKET OPENED IN 19-71.
THAT''S LESS THAN TWO MONTHS ... AFTER THE KEY INDEX BROKE THE THREE THOUSAND BARRIER.
THE NASDAQ FINISHED JUST UNDER 4-THOUSAND .... AFTER RISING MORE THAN 64 POINTS IN AFTERNOON TRADE ... TO HIT 4-THOUSAND AND ONE-POINT-SIX-THREE.
THE LATEST RALLY PUTS GAINS IN THE U-S OVER-THE-COUNTER MARKET UP BY 82 PERCENT FROM THE END OF LAST YEAR.

THAT''S ALL FOR NOW. STAY WITH US FOR MORE NEWS IN ABOUT TWO HOURS.
?

? On this Christmas Eve... Seoul''s Chamsil Olympic Stadium was full of action in the century''s last inter-Korean sport exchange.
? The final score came down to an even tie for the rival Koreas... with the South winning in the women''s division... while the North took the victory in the men''s game.
In the women''s round... the southern team got off to a head start in the first half... but the northern squad picked up steam in the second half... turning the game into a nail-biter.
Tonight... the North Korean side will host a dinner for officials from the Hyundai Group... in a show of appreciation for the Seoul visit.
The 62-member Pyongyang delegation returns to the North, tomorrow.?

? That is all from us on this Christmas eve.
We wish our viewers a happy holiday.
? Hope you all get to spend it in the warm company of loved ones.
Good night.?

Meeting Minutes for 12/24

**황사장님 plans to have MT early next year just for the news team.
사장님''s New Year message is on the Arirang BBS.

**Plans to build an office area on the 5th floor 옥상.

**12/29 3pm 인사위원회

**유부장님 and people at the meeting had a long discussion about last night''s news line-up... specifically about the omission of the KAL crash story.

? 1. why have concert at soysauce factory?
- to celebrate 40 year old factory''s move to a new location in Ichon(이천).
- Sempyo(54 yr old brand),  is trying to bridge the generation gap with teenagers... its future customers.
Therefore, has sought the help of Ssamzie(10 year), a young brand.
(The presidents of each company are old school mates, who met again last summer.)
Not just a one time thing, Sempyo plans more cultural events with Ssamzie, for the younger generation.
(Last Oct. the two held their first event at Yonsei U.)

2. Who''s appearing?
- Underground bands like Crying Nut, 황신혜 밴드, 어어부 프로젝트 etc

3. What else?
- Present sets for the 2000 concert attendees(handed out at the end of the concert)
Attendees applied for the tickets through internet
- Udon soup, made of Sempyo soysauce

? Tens of thousands in Seoul braved the cold and poured out onto the streets last night... ? to make the most of the millennium''s last Christmas eve.
Although the country got some snow yesterday... weather experts are telling people in the capital... not to keep their hopes up for more snow today.
Only the southern regions such as Choongchong (충청) and Cholla (전라) where a heavy snow warning is in effect this morning... will get to enjoy a White Christmas... for the first time in ten years.
Meanwhile... drivers are cautioned to watch out for road conditions... which remain icy and slippery.?

? Samsung Motors'' auto plant in the southeastern port city of Pusan... will likely be sold off by next February.
? Its parent... the Samsung Group says... two foreign companies... Renault and Fiat have shown interest in a takeover so far.
Currently under court receivership... Samsung Motors is still churning out new cars... hoping to pay off its debts.
This... after creditor banks decided this past October... to inject new loans and keep the carmaker open for three months.?

flexible hours... easy dress codes... no titles

? A new survey shows former Senator Bill Bradley now in the lead over Vice President Al  Gore... with just weeks remaining til the Democratic New Hampshire presidential primary.
? According to the American Research Group''s New Hampshire Poll on 600 likely voters... Bradley is leading Gore by 48 percent to 36 percent.
That''s with a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
The same poll had the two Democrats in a dead heat two weeks ago... in the state that holds the first primary of the presidential elections on February 1st.
Among Republicans, the poll also found Arizona Senator John McCain ahead of Texas Governor George Bush by nine points... 39 percent to 30 percent.?

Merry X-Mas!!!
Just a reminder that 7am news is only 10 minutes.
A big problem because there are so many stories.
I already asked 주조 if it''d be possible to lengthen the news to 13--15 minutes... but they said absolutely not.
When I talked to 국장님 earlier in the evening, he said to have an update on weather/X-Mas, basketball story, and Miryung''s apk... and then... the top ten news.
BUT THEN... 본부장님 called and said we must put in the 이상훈 Major League 진출 story as well as the "서울야경 밝아졌다" story (if you don''t have time, the 서울 broll can go in at night).
 Both videos are taped out "서울..." has lots of CGs.
본부장님 says take out the top ten news if you don''t have time.
Sorry, lots to tell you... at such early hour.

Good luck...
Jungeun

? Even with the chilly conditions... Seoul''s Chamsil Olympic Stadium... generated a lot of heat yesterday... as basketball teams from the two Koreas wrapped up a series of friendlies.
Reporter Cho Heemyung covered the games.

? 
??"After a day mixing players... it''s basketball showdown... South Korea versus North Korea. 
There may be a chill running across the 38th parellel on the Korean peninsula... but the mood is quite contrary here in Chamsil Olympic Gymnasium... jubilation and excitement... with 12-thousand spectators rooting for both sides."
(about five seconds of music and images...)
? "I want the North to take home a victory."
? "Unfortunately, you''ve got to have one winner. Of course, South Korea."
?	 "Hyundai."
?
 "I want it to be an even tie."
Well... he may have got his wish granted... 
In what made history as the two Korea''s final sports exchange this century... both Koreas came out a winner.
In the women''s round... the South''s Hyundai team got off to a head start in the first half thanks to strong shooting by Kim Young-ok(김영옥) and Park Myung-ae(박명애)... 
Then... the North''s Hoeori(회오리) or "Tornado" led by its star player Li Myung-wha(리명화) picked up steam in the second half... turning the game into a nail-biter... 
Ultimately... the victory went to the South''s Hyundai.
In the men''s round... it was a different story... with the North''s almighty Ri Myung-hoon towering everybody in all his 2-point-35 meters-height... earning his team Woorae(우뢰) or "Thunder" 28-points.
The final score came down in their favor with the North leading the South... 86-over-71.
The two-day basketball games... dubbed ? "reunification matches"... resulted in another agreement to hold a soccer friendly next year... giving rise to hopes such exchanges will ease tensions between the rival Koreas.
Two countries that are still ideological foes but friends in the arena of sports.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?

artcl_ctt:
?On this weeks Q and A, we have Dr. Kim Wan Soon ... from the office of the investment ombuds-man. He talks to us about how he resolves the difficulties foreign investors face in Korea.
?
?
 ? We have recurited 30 home doctors who are experts in various field such as labor, taxation and customs clearing, and also even some of the problems that the foreign community faces in their settlement.  And it''s just less than 2 months, but we have reported cases... reaching more than 170 cases. We think we have resolved about 110 cases and the rest are still pending.
In Korea we have about 5,000 foreign firms operating in Korea.  But we have initially contacted 600 firms and as we get experience we''d like to expand into about 2,000-3,000 firms this year and eventually next year.
And to improve our business more effeciently, we had meetings with American Chamber of Commerce, EU Chamber of Commerce and Seoul-Japan Club. These three countries are the largest investors in Korea.?

? ''Twas the night before Christmas... many people may be familiar with this tale about Jolly Saint Nick.
Most Chinese, however, have never heard of the man in Red... but that did not stop two Santas in Beijing... from going head to head... to prove who was the real Santa Claus.
Here''s a closer look.

? At this Beijing Shopping Mall... two Scandinavian Santas were out to prove their authenticity.
The Santa from Sweden claimed he was the real Santa because he his beard was real.
This left the Santa from Finland on shaky ground as he insisted so was his...
Noticeably, however, he didn''t submit his beard to a tug test.
The Finnish Ambassador to China took up the offensive, saying that the Swedish Santa was merely an assiastant of the Real Santa Claus.
? "A distant relative has also arrived in Beijing but the real Santa Claus of course we all know lives in Finnish Lapland- this ageless, timeless man has lived there for ten centuries.
And of course you see other Santa Clauses all over the world, but they are distant relatives and in many cases they are helpers of the real Santa Claus."
The children didn''t seem to care who was real... they were enraptured by both.
The Christmas holiday is a relatively new phenomenon in China and lost in all this commercialism is the religious significance behind the celebration.
Retailers are using the Santas to promote the holiday as another occasion to buy gifts and throw parties.
Christmas trees and decorations are now a common sight in most major cities... which is good news for our two jolly friends.
In the end, it was the Swedish Santa who resolved the issue...
he said that at heart... everyone who shares the spirit of giving is Santa Claus.?

? Having decided against merging... the two ruling coalition parties are now busy making their own preparations for next April''s general elections.
? The National Congress for New Politics is hoping to raise public interest... with the launch of its new party scheduled for January 20th.
NCNP lawmakers are currently recruiting district chapters... and are planning to work through this weekend setting the foundation for the new party.
Meanwhile... the United Liberal Democrats says it will begin its campaign in earnest... when Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil leaves his post... and returns to the party.
For the upcoming vote... the ULD is calling for joint nominations... based on equal representation between the two coalition partners... for regions other than their respective strongholds.
The NCNP, however, reportedly has reservations about this suggestion.?
artcl_titl: 2여 1야 총선채비#Ruling camp makes separate preparations for elections#
artcl_titl_en: 2여 1야 총선채비#Ruling camp makes separate preparations for elections#

artcl_ctt:
? Standard and Poor''s... has upgraded the long-term rating for Korea First Bank... from "B"... to "B-B-minus".
? The U-S credit rater... also raised the Bank''s short-term credit rating from "C" to "B"... and evaluated the long-term outlook as "stable."
The upgrades follow the sale of Korea First''s 51 percent stake and management to Newbridge Capital of the U-S.?
artcl_titl: S&P 제일은행(22KBR)#S&P upgrades Korea First Bank ratings#
artcl_titl_en: S&P 제일은행(22KBR)#S&P upgrades Korea First Bank ratings#

artcl_ctt:
? A local think tank believes... it will cost more to buy a home in Seoul... at the turn of the millennium... as real estate prices are on their way up again.
More on the story... by Lee Chung-yun(이정연).

?The Korea Research Institute for Human Settlements doesn''t expect household incomes and corporate investments to take a huge leap next year.
But that won''t stop real estate prices from rising... its latest report states.
According to analysts... the market is psychologically ready for property value to take a slow upswing... after suffering a prolonged slump.
In particular the report says... buyers looking for homes in Seoul and surrounding areas will see prices up by about 5 percent... while rent is also expected increase up at the same rate.
Also working on market forces is a fear that there''s a housing crunch.
?In turn... the institute predicts the construction sector will rebound from its depression during the first half of next year... and gain momentum in the second half... to post record growth at about 5 percent.
Lee Chung yun, Arirang TV.
?

? Working-level military officials from the two Koreas are sitting down for talks this Tuesday on relinking a severed cross-border railway... along with a highway alongside the tracks.
? The meeting... is the second to come this year... and is taking place at the Southern side''s Peace House in Panmunjom.
Aside from talks on the construction of the joint-rail project... the military contact is expected to set the schedule for a second meeting between South and North Korean defense ministers.?
artcl_titl: 오늘 2차 남북 군사실무위 개최#Working-level Military Talks#

artcl_ctt:
"SANTA CLAUS RALLY"

Korean stock prices, boosted by an overnight rally on Wall Street, record their third consecutive day of gains, as the benchmark index rises by 17 points.
-------------------------------
BASKETBALL WITHOUT BORDERS

North and South Korean basketball players wrap up a series of friendly matches in Seoul.  The 62-member squad from Pyongyang returns tomorrow.
-------------------------------
TARIFF QUOTA SYSTEM

The Finance-Economy Ministry says a new tariff quota system will take effect from January 1st, to make sure there is a steady supply of goods like hot coil, pulp, and quartz glass.
-------------------------------
HELP FOR INSURERS

Seoul plans to inject W2 trillion ($1.6 billion) in public funds into six major life insurers, before year''s end, ultimately to have healthier firms absorb weaker ones.

? The government is lifting land development restrictions from the so-called green belt zones.
? The laws were introduced 28 years ago... to protect the environment by controlling over-development.
As of next week... residents and businesses in the Shiwa(시화) Industrial Complex near the capital... will be able to build or expand their homes and factories.
And... greenbelt restrictions placed on some one-hundred-10 regions around the nation... will be abolished in phases... starting next March.
Cheju Island will see its zones relaxed from October.
Then in November... Chunchon (춘천), Chonju (전주) and Yosu (여수)... followed by Chongju (청주) and Jinju (진주) by the end of next year.?

? At least nine people are confirmed dead in the Philippine ferry accident.
? Rescuers this morning are still searching for the dozens missing... since the vessel carrying more than 650 passengers sank early Thursday.
More than 590 people have been pulled out of the waters so far.
While investigating for the cause of the sinking... some authorities believe the ferry went down after its hull hit a rock.
Recreational boaters and fishermen are helping to look for more survivors... in the waters off Cebu Island.?

?
?Korean stocks... boosted by an overnight rally on Wall Street... log their third straight day of gains.

?Basketball teams from both Koreas wrap up a series of friendlies in Seoul.

?And Seoul describes how the tariff quota system will change from the first of next year.?

?Hope you''re enjoying this holiday season.
Welcome to Arirang News.
I''m Ahn Chakhee in Seoul.
?And I''m Hyun Chulho.
This is the final edition for December 24th.?

?The "Nogunri" you kept hearing about this year is a village in North Chungchong Province... where U.S. troops might have opened fire on hundreds of unarmed South Korean civilians in the early days of the Korean War.
The alleged killings happened about a month after war broke out... with US planes dropping bombs on a group of refugees... and soldiers firing machine guns into the crowd.

??("At that time, under concentrated fire, I was surprised and escaped by myself.  I went this way, crawling through the stream."

An overzealous military campaign going after possible North Korean infiltrators in the group?
A break in the chain of command?
Or memories of what happened that may be too selective?
To get to the truth... Korean and U.S. military investigators are conducting a joint probe... interviewing Nogunri residents and veterans... going through war documents... and even opening an Internet site to collect additional information from those who might have it.

??"I have been directed to conduct a thorough and comprehensive review to determine the facts and to determine what occurred at Nogunri."

And for now... the general consensus is to wrap things up... before next June... and the 50th anniversary of the Korean War.

Meanwhile... in the news last month... were the same acknowledgements in Seoul and Washington... that 60-thousand tons of harmful defoliants were sprayed along the Korean Peninsula''s Demilitarized Zone in the late 60''s.
These included the cancer-causing Agent Orange... as well as Agent Blue and Monuron.
There was a fair amount of finger-pointing as to who first suggested the spraying idea.
But the Pentagon later said the U.S. had raised it... to get a clearer view of North Korea... as a defense tactic.
Seoul''s Defense Ministry''s working on a draft revision bill to support both veterans and civilians who might''ve been exposed to the agents.
And 20 Korean victims have filed a compensation suit against U.S. chemical companies and the U.S. government.
An ensuing legal battle could take years...but observers at this point say... there''s a greater chance for an out-of-court settlement.

"Nogunri" and Agent Orange.
Two topics of 1999... related in that they''re about the search for truth... surrounding events of the past... with possible repercussions for the future.
(cut to anchor after pan stops)?
artcl_titl: TOP 10:노근리/고엽제#''99 review: military past haunts present#
artcl_titl_en: TOP 10:노근리/고엽제#''99 review: military past haunts present#

artcl_ctt:
? Good Morning.
Although a white Christmas is NOT expected in Korea this year...
If you''ve looked outside... you''d know that the peninsula is waking up to a white Christmas eve this morning.
As much as eight centimeters of snow is expected in Seoul before the day is over.
Checking the temperatures for you...
Lows are ranging from minus two to seven degrees Celsius...
Eleven degrees is the highest it will get today.?

? That is our report for this Friday morning... December 24th.
We hope to see you back here same time tomorrow.
In the meantime... thank you very much for watching and happy holidays!?

?On the weather front... up to six centimeters of snow fell overnight ? in Seoul and the surrounding Kyonggi area... where a heavy snow warning''s been in effect today.
At the moment, ALL roads in Seoul are opened to traffic... but certain sections are said to be slippery... so drivers are asked to take extra care this morning.
Authorities say they may close some roads later on if need be.
Fortunately, temperatures have stayed relatively warm.?
artcl_titl: 눈길 조심, 대설주의보#Snowfall in Seoul and Kyonggi#
artcl_titl_en: 눈길 조심, 대설주의보#Snowfall in Seoul and Kyonggi#

artcl_ctt:
? Former presidential aide Park Joo-sun (박주선) was arrested early this morning... for leaking confidential papers on the so-called ''furgate'' scandal.
? He is charged with handing over investigative reports... filed by a police team under the presidential office... to former Prosecutor-General Kim Tae-joung.
Kim''s wife was a central figure in the scandal... in which expensive clothes were allegedly used as bribes.
Park is also accused of holding back witness testimony from the prosecution... information that would have worked against Kim''s wife.
Park insists, though... he''s not guilty of any wrongdoing.?
artcl_titl: 박주선 구속 수감#Ex-presidential aide arrested for paper leak#
artcl_titl_en: 박주선 구속 수감#Ex-presidential aide arrested for paper leak#

artcl_ctt:
? Overnight in New York... Wall Street closed for the Christmas holidays on a very merry note.
Its three main indices surged to their highest closings for the year... after enjoying what investors refer to as... the Santa Claus rally.
Here''s a recap of the market action.

? It''s been a record breaking day on Wall Street.
All three major indexes soared into record territory.
?The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 202 points to 11,405... ? beating out the previous record set back in August.
?The S-and-P 500 Index was also up.
It advanced 22-points to 1,458... ?overtaking its record high from earlier this month.
But the big surprise came when the NASDAQ surged more than 64 points in early afternoon trading... to hit four-thousand and one-point-six-three.
That''s the first time that the tech-heavy index shot through the 4-thousand level since it opened 28-years ago.
?At the end of trading, the NASDAQ index retreated to just below four thousand... at 3,969.? 
With the latest rally... NASDAQ is now up by a stunning 82 percent... for the year.
Investors are pouring so much money into the market that the NASDAQ has gained an unprecedented 1-thousand points in just a little over a month.
The market opened in 19-71... and most of the issues traded on the NASDAQ are related to computer and the Internet.?

Nakwon means paradise in Korean and that''s what the workers there are trying to accomplish through relentless efforts in machinery production.
Enjoy this incredible story of achievement through the will of the people.

? The World Trade Organization says the super 3-0-1 trade clause of the United States... does not go against W-T-O regulations.
? But, the trade body says Washington should get W-T-O approval... before imposing sanctions under the clause.
The European Union disagrees... saying super 3-0-1 is one-sided... and does not help global trade.
Under the clause... Washington can impose sanctions on trading partners... for unfair practices.?
artcl_titl: WTO, "미 통상법 301조 규정 위배 안돼"#Super 301 does not violate WTO rules#
artcl_titl_en: WTO, "미 통상법 301조 규정 위배 안돼"#Super 301 does not violate WTO rules#

artcl_ctt: ?Hello and welcome to Trading Post.?

?That''s it for this weeks Trading Post.
Please contact us if you have any ideas for the show, and thanks for watching.?

? Washington is warning Americans across the world to be on the lookout for any terrorist attacks... during the  millennium celebrations .
Since putting out its second worldwide caution this month, authorities are tightening security around the nation''s airports, government offices and border regions.

? U-S President Bill Clinton issued a new global travel advisory to Americans worldwide... extending the warning time period by another week... to mid-January.
Clinton said his government was taking extraordinary measures to thwart guerilla attacks around New Year''s Eve... beefing up security at airports, border stations, federal buildings at home and abroad.
For the next few weeks... all 301-points of entry to the U-S will be on a heightened alert.
Citing new investigative data... U-S defense secretary William Cohen said Washington was working hard to protect its citizens by cooperating with allied spy agencies worldwide... adding Americans should keep a low profile by avoiding large crowds and gatherings.
Analysts say such move reflects Wednesday''s arrest of a suspected terrorist in the U-S who tried to smuggle explosive devices from Canada.
Observors say the incident sparked fresh concerns for neighboring Canada as it began increasing security at its international border crossings and airports.
However, Canadian authorities denied they were acting on pressure from the U-S.?

? President Kim Dae-jung will meet with Park Tae-jun.... leader of the ruling coalition partner ... and discuss ways to closely cooperate for next April''s general elections.
? The meeting follows yesterday''s agreement between the president and Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil... NOT to merge the two ruling parties.
Kim is also expected to touch on other issues including the on-going controversy surrounding changes to the current electoral system.?

artcl_titl_en: 김대통령, 박태준 총재 오늘 주례 회동

? The Daewoo Corporation is inching closer to court receivership.
? Final audit results show the company has chalked up an additional 2-point-8 trillion won in debts.
There are few banks or financial institutions willing to accept the extra burden.
Foreign creditors say... the current debt buyout proposal is unacceptable... because it is based on inaccurate and unreliable data.
A senior government official said yesterday, that if foreign lenders officially reject the proposal... Korean and local creditors... will likely apply for court-supervised liquidation, next week.
The Daewoo Corporation has about 32-trillion won in liabilities.
Meanwhile... the Korea Stock Exchange halted transactions of the company''s shares this morning.?
artcl_titl: 대우 법정관리 불가피 # Court Receivership Looms for Daewoo Corp.#
artcl_titl_en: 대우 법정관리 불가피 # Court Receivership Looms for Daewoo Corp.#

artcl_ctt:
? A sign that the economy is recovering... Korea''s Pusan Port handled more than 6 ?million containers in 19-99 .... a record high.
The figures are based on containers measuring 20 feet long.
By the end of the year... the total is expected to top 6-point-2 million.
That''s an 8 percent rise from last year.
The number of containers is even greater than that handled at the world''s fourth largest port last year... the Netherlands'' Rotterdam Port.?
artcl_titl: 부산 수출 커테이너 600만개 돌파 # Pusan Port Handled More than 6 mil. Containers #
artcl_titl_en: 부산 수출 커테이너 600만개 돌파 # Pusan Port Handled More than 6 mil. Containers #

?Korea''s average unemployment rate next year...  is forecast to be four-point-three percent.
?The Korea Labor Institute says... that means around 820-thousand people will be newly hired... while the number of those without a job will be just under 960-thousand.
The jobless rate is expected to be slightly higher than now... during next year''s first half.
Reasons cited are seasonal factors... and new graduates entering the job market.
But, the situation should improve in the latter half.
Meanwhile, job uncertainties will continue to be a problem... as many workers are expected to hold temporary or part-time positions.?

artcl_titl_en: 노동연구원, "내년 실업률 4.3%"#2000 umemployment rate to fall to 4.3%#

? In related news... a senior official at the Presidential Office of Chongwadae says... the final days of this year... could see a meeting between President Kim and opposition leader Lee Hoi-chang.
? The official added though... much will depend on talks between ruling and opposition lawmakers... and the progress they make on key issues.
Issues... including the arrest of Grand National Party member Chung Hyung-keun(정형근), and a parliamentary probe into the press control scandal.
Chongwadae official said... rival camps have agreed to put aside their differences, and work together to restore stability and public trust in politics.?
