artcl_ctt:
? Maritime officials from Korea and Japan have reached an agreement on next year''s fishing quota in each other''s exclusive economic zones, or E-E-Z.
Korea''s quota has been lowered by 19-thousand tons for next year.
We have more in this story.

? Korean fishermen can expect a decrease in how much fish they can catch next year in Japan''s Exclusive Economic Zone.
According to an agreement reached yesterday in Tokyo... the Korean fishing quota has been reduced by 19-thousand tons... which means Korea will only be allowed to catch 130-thousand tons in the Japanese E-E-Z.
Working level meetings started Monday in the Japanese capital... to determine the quantity and the methods of fishing in each others'' waters.
As a result, the number of Korean fishing vessels allowed to enter Japan''s E-E-Z was also cut by 65... to 1639.
Meanwhile, Japan will be allowed to catch up to 94-thousand tons of fish in Korea''s E-E-Z... while 15-hundred Japanese vessels have been given the green light to operate in Korean waters.
That''s approximately the same amount as this year''s quota.
Earlier this year, the two countries ratified a revised fisheries agreement... by which both countries will gradually have the same fishing quotas in three years.
That''s why Korea''s fishing quota was cut by 19-thousand tons this time around.
As for the controversial waters near Tokto... an island claimed by both sides... Seoul and Tokyo agreed to let each government implement its own regulations.
The two countries will finalize next year''s fisheries conditions in Seoul early next week.?

Our animated feature this week emphasizes the importance of one''s beliefs.
It shows that one''s vigilent stance can overcome evil.
Let''s watch.

? A Korean company has developed a kit that can detect HIV infection within minutes.
The maker of the quick and inexpensive product... Dong-A Pharmaceuticals... already has several interested countries knocking on its door.
Here''s more.

? The makers compare it to a home pregnancy kit. Indeed researchers at Dong-A Pharmaceuticals have developed a process that seems much too simple... to diagnose such a grave condition.
It works like this... one or two drops of blood are placed in the circular port of the plastic strip.
And after three minutes or less... the results show in the rectangular window.
One line means negative... while two means positive.
?"The rapidness of the detection system is quite amazing."
The kit makes it possible to do away with costly testing procedures.
But Dong-A isn''t the first to come up with such a kit.
Similar one''s have been developed by U-S laboratories.
What differentiates the Korean company''s kit from their competitors says the company... is the cost.
The Dong-A kit will sell for one third of the price at about one dollar per kit.
The kits will hit the market in January... but don''t expect to see them in pharmacies... because they will only be distributed to hospitals and clinics.
?"Because if privately sold then the person who knows he is infected by HIV may escape from the government surveilance, and it can cause big problems in epidemics."
With inquires flooding in from Russia, South Africa, and South Asian countries... Dong-A expects to gross three million dollars in exports in just the first half of next year.?

? North and South Korean basketball players met face-to-face today on the court.
? In the first of the two-day basketball friendlies... athletes from the two Koreas were regrouped into mixed teams... to play against each other.
The final score in the women''s round came down to 133-over-125... with Tanhap(단합) or the "unity" team winning over Tankeul(단결) or the "solidarity" team.
Some 12-thousand spectators packed the Chamsil Olympic stadium to watch the century''s last inter-Korean sports exchanges.
Tomorrow, the North Korean teams will square off against South Korean players... from Hyundai.?

? Let''s begin as always... with a look through what''s in the local dailies.

? First off, a joint project to develop semiconductor technology.
Six companies from Korea, the U-S, Japan and Germany will form a consortium to do research on next generation D-RAM computer chips.
The multinational consortium will be set up early next year... and by 2002, new products could be out on the production lines.

Korea and Japan have reached an agreement on the terms for next  year''s fishing quota in their exclusive economic zones.
The two sides also agreed on the joint management of maritime resources in the provisional zones between the two countries.
Those are the results of three-days of working level fisheries talks in Tokyo.

They''re the hottest items this Christmas... anything and everything to do with the Pokemon phenomeon.
Characters... including the yellow Picachu... from the Japanese cartoon have grabbed the hearts of children all over the country.
And a toy manufacturer is donating 2000 adorable teddy bears to hospitalized children.
The furry creatures have a message on one of the paws which reads, "Be Happy."

Getting to our top story.?

?Unification Minister Lim Dong-won (임동원) was appointed today as the new director of the National Intelligence Service.
?He''ll replace Cheon Yong-taek (천용택)... recently under fire... for his remarks... the president had accepted political funds from a local business group... before being elected.
?The 65-year-old Lim was a former Senior Presidential Secretary for Foreign Affairs and National Security.... and is a key architect of President Kim''s "sunshine" policy of engaging North Korea.
?Meanwhile, Kyungnam University President and North Korea expert Park Je-kyu(박재규) will take over Lim''s post as Unification Minister.?

artcl_ctt:
? Foreign investments in Korea this year broke the 10-billion dollar mark for the first time in history.
In fact... according to the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy... the country has already broken its annual target of 15 billion.
Here''s more.

? By the end of this year... Seoul expects foreign investments to total 15-point-5 billion dollars.
That... the Commerce Ministry says... is the highest in history... since the country opened its doors.
As of this Tuesday... the country lured 2-thousand and 20 cases this year... or in dollars... 15-point-2 billion.
This record figure also bumps up Korea seven notches to 14th biggest attracter of foreign investments this year... in the world.
? Four decades ago... when the peninsula first welcomed foreign investments... 3-point-6 million dollars washed ashore.
Money continued to flow into the country... to surpass one billion in 19-87... and then jump another ten fold to break 10 billion this year.?
Given this... ? total foreign investments for Korea... including this year... would amount to 49 billion dollars.
Of the sum... almost half came after the economic crisis of late 19-97.?
By industry... the service industry is the biggest winner... grabbing more than 55 percent of investments... worth 8-point-3 billion dollars.
The European Union invested the most in Korea this year pouring in more than 6 billion dollars... followed by the United States and Japan.?

artcl_titl_en: 외국인 투자 150억 돌파#Foreigners invest $15 billion plus#

artcl_ctt:
? The recent floods in Venezuela are being called the worst natural disaster of the century in the Latin American country.
And experts say... we can expect to see more such weather calamities.

?At first there was Hurricane Mitch... followed by severe flooding in Colombia and Mexico... and most recently the disaster in Venezuela....It''s been a year of  severe weather.
Why this year... why now...
Experts are blaming it on global warming..
more specifically ... El Nino and La Nina... weather patterns which warm the Pacific Ocean one year and cool it the next. 
They beleive the current cooling effect of La Nina has brought prolonged and torrential rain to the Atlantic coast of Central America.
However... global warming is just one matter... meteorlogist say manmade conditions add to the scale of destruction.
In Venezuela, deforestation has stripped mountains of tropical forests that once aborbed rain... now running into valleys where people live.
A challenge presents itself... as man claims more land for housing and farming... and global warming continues unabated.?

?The Tokyo stock market is closed today... as the nation celebrates Emperor Akihito''s birthday.
As for other markets around the region....

?Shares in Hong Kong rose on the back of Internet and telecom shares.
Boosted by another record breaking session in the tech-heavy Nasdaq... the Hang Seng rose one-hundred-three points to 16-thousand-296.
China Telecom and Pacific Century led the gainers on the island territory.
 
Over in Singapore, the Straits Times Index climbed to an intra-day high of 24-24 surging 40 points.
Computer related stocks led the rise.

Meanwhile bucking the trend... Sydney''s All Ordinaries finished in the red... its third decline in four days.
The index shed 24-points to close at 31-17-and-a-half.
Telstra... the country''s second-biggest company by market value... lost ground as investor concerns about increased competition kicked in.

And finally... let''s see how the Korean won fared against other regional currencies.?

?Here''s a new toy that is almost as good as having a pet.
?Their called Eggbos... produced by a local company... Top Development.
The maker says... these little creatures can talk among themselves, express emotions such as love and sadness... and even tell you when they''re hungry.
 Eggbos can also sing 15 different tunes.
A memory chip and an infrared sensor in each of these critters allow them to interact with each other and their owners.
The company says... the toys are geared toward teenagers and twenty-somethings.
?

? Tech savvy children around the world won''t be checking out the night sky looking for Santa on this  Christmas eve...
They''re going be monitoring their computer screens... to get hourly updates on the whereabouts of Saint Nick.
Here''s the story.

?Deep in the mountains of Colorado... is America''s satellite tracking command.
Home to some sophisticated machinery.. that tracks ballistic missiles.
Things are usually pretty quiet around here... except this time of year.. 
?"We should give a live update shortly, we are anticipating at the top of the hour so we will give kids an update on where Santa Clause is."..
?"Hey Larry we''ve got Santa Clause, he''s on, we''ve got our first images. That''s great we can put this on the site."
It all began in 19-55 by telephone..as children called the command to find out how close Santa was to their house.
These day''s though... modern technology allows Santa''s progress to be monitored via the home computer...
? "We discovered a number of years ago that the system is so sophisticated that it can actually track Rudolph the red nose reindeer''s nose, the heat. Everyone has heard that his nose glows all so bright but it also emits a significant infra-red heat source."
NORAD says the site gets half a million hits a day with a lot of interest from Japanese children.
There are hourly updates... lasting about 20 seconds showing Santa riding his sleigh over places of world interest.
?"Oh yeah, there he is I see him."
It seems Santa has many helpers.?

? WELCOME TO NEWSROOM UPDATE. OUR TOP STORY TODAY....

? A KOREAN AIR CARGO PLANE CRASHED SOME FOUR HOURS AGO SHORTLY ATER TAKEOFF FROM BRITAIN''S STANSTED AIRPORT... SOME 40 KILOMETERS NORTH OF LONDON.
? POLICE SAY THE BODIES OF THREE... OF THE FOUR CREW ON BOARD WERE FOUND... WITH THE REMAINING PERSON FEARED DEAD.
KOREAN AIR OFFICIALS HERE SAY ALL THE CREW MEMBERS ARE OF KOREAN NATIONALITY.
THE CRASH OCCURRED MINUTES AFTER THE PLANCE DEPARTED FOR MILAN ... ITALY ... AT 18:40 G-M-T... OR ABOUT 3:40 A.M. SEOUL TIME.? WITNESSES SAID THE PLANE CAME DOWN ON OPEN GROUND NEAR THE TOWN OF GREAT HALLINGBURY... SOME 5 KILOMETERS SOUTHEAST OF THE AIRPORT.

? PRESIDENT KIM DAE-JUNG WILL MEET TODAY WITH THE LEADER OF THE RULING COALITION PARTNER.... PARK TAE-JUN.... TO DICUSS WAYS OF COOPERATING IN NEXT APRIL''S GENERAL ELECTIONS.
THE SCHEDULED MEETING FOLLOWS YESTERDAY''S AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE PRESIDENT AND PRIME MINISTER KIM JONG-PIL NOT TO MERGE THE TWO RULING PARTIES ... AND CONTINUE TO MAINTAIN A COALITION GOVERNMENT.
KIM IS ALSO EXPECTED TO TOUCH ON OTHER ISSUES INCLUDING AN ON-GOING CONTROVERSY SURROUNDING CHANGES TO THE CURRENT ELECTORAL SYSTEM.

? PROSECUTORS TODAY ARRESTED PARK JOO-SON .... FORMER PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARY ON JUDICIAL AFFAIRS... FOLLOWING A COURT APPROVAL OF HIS ARREST WARRANT.
PARK IS CHARGED WITH HANDING OVER INVESTIGATIVE REPORTS ON A CLOTHES-FOR-LOBBYING SCANDAL... TO FORMER PROSECUTOR-GENERAL KIM TAE-JUNG. 
KIM''S WIFE WAS IMPLICATED IN THE SCANDAL... IN WHICH EXPENSIVE CLOTHING WERE ALLEGED TO HAVE BEEN USED AS BRIBES.
PARK IS ALSO CHARGED WITH HOLDING BACK WITNESS TESTIMONY FROM THE PROSECUTION ... INFORMATION THAT COULD HAVE WORKED AGAINST KIM''S WIFE.

FOR UPDATES ON THESE AND OTHER STORIES TUNE IN FOR MORE NEWS IN ABOUT TWO HOURS. THANKS FOR WATCHING.?

? A local venture company says it''s developed a cellular phone that''s able to identify its user.. by recoginizing his or her finger print.
Here''s more on what it does.

? The modern day reliance on credit cards and automated cash dispensers really stem from one need... identifying the individual.
One Korean venture company thinks it''s created the one thing that''ll eventually rid the world of passwords and door locks.
Think of it as a cellular phone that''s really a master key... or Pass Phone... as the product is called.
The developer... Pass 21st Century ... claims the technology is completely error-free unlike previous finger-print recognition equipment.
Such equipment commonly saw limitations in recognizing damaged tissue ... and were always susceptible to good fakes.
Pass 21st says.... their technology looks a little closer at finger tips... closer that is... on the genetic level and therefore can only be fool-proof.
The result is a cell-phone that can ... for example .... communicate with cash or credit card machines... toll booths, computerized locks or any number of secured facilities... to provide the user with services based on confirmed identity.
The company says mass production of the wonder phone... is just six months away... to be taken up by the nation''s top electronics maker... Samsung.
?

Hello and welcome to this Christmas edition of Eye on North Korea.
I''m Kim Boram... I hope you enjoying your holiday.

 North Korea and Japan will meet again some time early next year... for further talks on normalizing ties. That was about all officials from the two sides could agree on... during their two-day preliminary meeting in Beijing, China this past week.
Officials from the two sides were reportedly unable to work out their differences over some key issues... like the alleged kidnapping of Japanese citizens by North Korean agents... Pyongyang''s missile program... and Tokyo''s resumption of food aid to the communist state.
Officials have yet to set an agenda for higher-level diplomatic talks on normalizing relations.
Meanwhile, Red Cross delegations from both countries also met in Beijing where it was agreed that the Japanese Red Cross would urge its government to resume shipments of food aid.
The North Korean Red Cross agreed to work with relevant authorities to investigate the alleged kidnappings.

Now for a look at what''s been happening up North.?

? A Korean Air cargo plane crashed just hours ago... shortly after takeoff from Britain''s Standsted Airport... some 40 kilometers north of London.
? An airport spokesperson said all four crew members on board... are believed to have died in the crash.
One body has reportedly been found.
Korean Air officials here say all the crew members are of Korean nationality.
The crash occurred minutes after taking off for Milan, Italy at 18:40 G-M-T... that''s about 3:40 a.m. Korean time.
Witnesses said the plane came down on open ground near the town of Great Hallingbury... some 5 kilometers southeast of the airport.... and appeared to have hit power lines as the whole village was suddently without electricity.
It is not yet known what caused the crash.
We will bring you updates on the story throughout the day as it develops.?

? Contrary to earlier expectations... the nation''s businesses are likely to end the year without a major liquidity problem.
Suk Min has more on a recent study by the central bank.

? The Bank of Korea says large conglomerates should not have any problem... in paying back maturing loans... at year''s end.
The B-O-K says company finances are stable due to an increase in revenue... and the offering of new shares.
The top four business groups, namely Samsung, Hyundai, L-G, and S-K... have acquired 20-trillion won... through recapitalization this year.
That''s a three-fold increase from last year.
As for smaller businesses... their new share offerings doubled to 14-trillion won.
These firms are not likely to face extra pressure from banks... contrary to some gloomy predictions earlier this year.
Many banks had to set aside additional loss reserves for exposure to the embattled Daewoo Group.
Despite the move... the banks say they''ll be able to meet the eight percent capital adequacy ratio by year''s end.
The additional reserves should be covered by repayments from large conglomerates... and banks do not plan on recovering loans extended to smaller businesses.
The Y-2-K computer bug had been another area of concern...
?However, the corporate sector doesn''t  see the need for extra cash at the ?year''s end... since the deadline for loan repayments and tax dues... have been pushed back to January fourth...
Financial institutions will be closed until the third of January... as a safety precaution against the millennium computer bug.
Suk Min, Arirang TV.?

? A blackbox has been recovered from a Korean Air cargo plane which crashed early this morning in England.
The jumbo jet had just taken off from Standsted Airport... some 40 kilometers north of London... and was headed for Milan.
Three bodies have been found and one other crew member is feared dead.
The details in this report.

? Minutes after taking off... the Korean Air cargo plane slammed into open ground near the town of Great Hallingbury... ? some five kilometers southeast of the airport.
The plane which was heading to Milan, Italy... narrowly missed houses and appeared ? to have hit power lines as the entire village was without electricity.
? "Basically we were sitting down in our kitchen and there was a massive light flash and a big bang and the whole house shook".
Korean Air officials in Seoul identified all the crew members as Korean... but said it was too early to speculate on the cause of the crash.
It was initially thought the plane may have been carrying toxic material... but this was later discounted by the police.
? "We were at one stage concerned about what the cargo might have been because we were unsure and we''re still unsure about what the cargo is but there was no report of any toxic-gas."
Britain''s Air Accident Investigations Branch confirmed that one of the two black boxes aboard... the cockpit voice recorder... had been recovered.
It was not known if the crew had tried to contact controllers or report anything wrong.
It was the second such cargo plane crash at the airlines this year.
In April... a Korean Air MD11 cargo jet crashed shortly after take-off at Shanghai airport killing eight... including three of its crew.
? The recent series of plane accidents at Korea''s flagship air carrier and the world''s 13th-largest airline.... has prompted Seoul to issue penalties... including a government ban last month on adding new international routes and flights for one year.?

for leaking confidential documents on the so called ''furgate'' scandal.
Park Ju-sun (박주선) is accused of handing over investigative reports... filed by a police detachment to the presidential office... to former prosecutor-general Kim Tae-jung.
Kim''s wife was implicated in the scandal... in which expensive clothes were allegedly used as bribes.
Park is also charged with holding back witness testimony from the prosecution... information that would have worked against Kim''s wife.
Park insists, though... he''s not guilty of any wrongdoing.?

? Rescue efforts are underway to save passengers from a ferry accident in the central Philippines.

inter-Korean basketball friendlies, in Seoul.
? Professional teams of the two Koreas held a series of games for two days at Chamsil Olympic Stadium.
On Thursday... male and female athletes from both sides played WITH each other on the same teams.
Then on Friday... the North Korean teams squared off against their southern counterparts from Hyundai.
Pyongyang broadcast the games live via satellite to its viewers.
Among the North Korean players was the world''s tallest known basketball player... Ri Myung-hoon... who is 7-foot-9 or about 2-point-35 meters tall.?

The index at one point... surged above the one-thousand mark... as aggressive buying from overseas investors continued.
But profit taking by institutional players and local investment trust firms... ate into those earlier gains.
Computer and telecom shares were the big winners.
A total of 293 million shares were exchanged on turnover of 4-and-a-half trillion won.
Meanwhile, trading on the FX counters was slow this Thursday.
The Korean currency gained eight-tenths of a won against the US dollar from yesterday... to close at one-thousand-130-point-7 won.?

?The Light Wave Oven named ''Advantium'' has been chosen as this year''s best product... by the U-S magazine... Business Week.
Here''s more.
?The Light Wave Oven... was jointly developed by L-G Electronics and General Electric.
And it seems like they have succeeded in opening up a niche in high quality home appliances. 
Selected as this year''s best product by the U-S magazine Business Week... the Light Wave Oven is praised to be both innovative and efficient.
Using light as the source of heat... the up-and-coming oven cuts the average cooking time by a third.
L-G''s latest innovation has earn the company worldwide recognition in both technology and quality.
Its price is set at around a relatively high 13-hundred dollars... but, so far, more than 20-thousand units have been sold since September.
By next year though... the company expects to see a 150-percent growth each year in the U-S.
And, by the year 2003... L-G hopes to establish a total market size of around 4-hundred million dollars.?

? The government has promised one-point-two trillion won... ? or a little over one-billion dollars in aid to Taebaek(태백) city in Kangwon Province.
The funding... brings an end to two weeks of protests by the local residents who had been demanding state assistance to revive the region''s economy.
Under an agreement reached by the two sides yesterday... the government will provide 100-billion won a year, for the next ten years... to the city''s coal mining industry.
Plus... an additional 200-billion won will go toward revitalizing Taebaek(태백) city''s economy.?

?The KOSPI gained 6-points... to close at 974.
The index at one point... surged above the thousand mark... as aggressive buying from overseas investors continued.
However, profit taking by institutional players and local investment trust firms... ate into those earlier gains.
Computer and telecom shares were the big winners today.
A total of 293 million shares were exchanged on turnover of 4-and-a-half trillion won.
Decliners outpaced advancers... while 44 issues remained steady.
67 hit their daily limit highs and only 9 sank to their lows.

Time now... for a look at some of Korea''s major stocks.?

? US consortium Newbridge Capital has officially taken over Korea First Bank.
This is the first time a foreign firm is assuming a local company''s shares and management... at the same time.
A closer look at the deal, in this report.

? Thursday''s signing ceremony put an 
?end to nearly 2 years of efforts by the government to sell Korea First Bank.
The sale had been one of the conditions put forth by the IMF, when it gave Korea emergency bailout loans in 19-97.
The government finally sold a 51 percent stake to the US equity firm Newbridge... for 500 billion won, about 440 million dollars.
It will retain the other 49 percent share.
The contract says Newbridge must inject 200 billion won into the bank over the next two years... depending on how operations go.
The US company will also take over the bank''s complete loan portfolio... including workout debts.
Non-performing debts will be left to the Korea Asset Management Corporation.
Newbridge named a Japanese-American, Wilfred  Horie, from the Associate First Capital Corporation, to head the new bank.
Former Korean Minister of Trade, Industry and Energy, Kim Chul-soo has been named vice-chairman on the board of directors.
The new management will take office on January 4th, after a shareholder''s meeting, on December 30th.?
artcl_titl: Korea First-Newbridge # Newbridge Officially Takes Over Korea First #
artcl_titl_en: Korea First-Newbridge # Newbridge Officially Takes Over Korea First #

? According to a leading government think-tank... the Korean economy is expected to grow by about eight percent next year.
But it also says rising prices could put a damper on such a rosy forecast.
Here''s a closer look at the report.

? Next year''s economic growth rate is forecast to reach 7-point-8 percent... due to stable market conditions and economic recovery.
So says the Korea Development Institute in an economic outlook released Thursday.
According to KDI... ?gross domestic product is forecast to reach 13-percent in the fourth quarter of this year.
That figure compares with the 4-point-5 percent growth posted in the first quarter... bringing the forecast for this year''s annual GDP growth rate to just over 10-percent.
However... GDP growth it says... will likely slow down next year for an annual rate of 7-point-8 percent.?
Consumer prices... expected to rise less than one percent this year... is forecast to rise to 4-percent during the latter half of next year. 
Both exports and imports are expected to fall... resulting in a smaller current-account surplus of 12 billion dollars next year... from this year''s projection of 25 billion.
However... the institute adds growth and inflation figures next year will undoubtedly be affected by the pace and scope of economic restructuring.
?It says rising prices could result in a highly unstable environment for local businesses... expected to be pressured by wage hikes and higher interest rates.
One reason... the KDI says top priority should be placed on stablilizing prices.
Shim Miryung Arirang TV.?

? The transport sector and customs officials are taking special measures to prepare for the Y2K glitch.
Shipping firms are putting employees on emergency standby.
They''re also stocking up on 10 days'' worth of fuel and food just in case.
As for airlines... they are trying to avoid being in the air for any long distances during the year end.
19 carriers, including Korean Air, have cancelled flights on the 31st and 1st to Bangkok, where Y2K is said to remain a risk.
Customs offices will be doing their part to speed up procedures... inspecting goods only by computer.?

? The 23rd bridge crossing the Han River in Seoul is now open.
? Called the Chungdam(청담) Bridge... the structure connects Seoul''s Kangnam District... south of the river... to Kwangjin(광진) District in the north.
It''s the nation''s first bi-level bridge... allowing subways to run on the bottom and cars on the top level.
South bound lanes connect with roads leading to the satellite city of Pundang... while the opposite lanes... lead to the expressway along the northern bank of the Han River.?

And it also says the ship''s name... "M-V Asia South Korea"... has no relation to this country.
The Korean embassy in Manila says the ship was built in Japan and is registered in the Philippines.?

? The two ruling coalition parties say they''ll continue to push corporate restructuring and...? solve the debate on remapping Korea''s voting districts.
The agreement came during a weekly meeting between President Kim Dae-jung... leader of the National Congress for New Politics... and Park Tae-joon... who heads the United Liberal Democrats.
Following the talks... Park said he and the President also agreed... on-going corporate reform measures should be wrapped up by year''s end... including the Daewoo Group issue.?

artcl_titl_en: DJ-TJ(22BA)#Pres meets coalition partner to discuss state affairs#

artcl_ctt:
? Now to... basketball without borders.
We take you courtside... to a series of friendly matches between players of the two Koreas... being held in southern Seoul.
Cho Heemyung reports.

? For the first time in nine-years... the two Koreas met face-to-face in Seoul... putting aside their different ideolgies for the sake of sportsmanship.
The event comes amid better economic ties between the rival Koreas... with the South''s largest conglomerate Hyundai spearheading the way for greater exchanges.
In the first of the two-day basketball friendlies... North and South Korean athletes got a chance to know each other better... regrouped into mixed teams.
One definite star... was Ri Myung-hoon... the world''s tallest player... looking almighty in all his 7-foot-9... or 2-point-35-meters height.
Ri''s team Tankeul(단결) or "Solidarity"...  lost to Tanhap(단합)... or "Unity" by a slight margin.
But Ri proved he not only outstood others in size but skill... earning Tankeul... 24-points.
Another attraction was the acrobatic troupe from North Korea.
Tens of thousands of fans oohed... and aahed... every time they did their mega-twists and turns.
?? "The game... which is a follow-up to a September match in the communist North... will be the last in a decade of sports exchanges that have yielded mixed results at best."
Nonetheless... the 12-thousand spectators packed into Seoul''s Chamsil Olympic Stadium put aside their political opinions.
While the older generation stressed the significance of the games... 
?? "We''ve always wanted to see unification through sports exchanges... I can''t believe it''s happening today."
Most of the younger crowds said it just felt great.
? 
?  
And... some appeared to be more interested in the fact North Koreans were here in the South.
?	?
 "I want the South to win." 
(comment) But it''s a mixed group today...
But regardless of whose side they were on... the excitement was evident.
?
?  "Quite happy to see there''s communication going on between the two Koreas. Very pleased."
On Christmas Eve... the two Koreas will face off each other... for a game of hoops aimed at stoking goodwill between the longtime rivals.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: Inter-Korean Basketball for 22:00 - the First Match-up#Inter-Korean Basketball - the First Match-up#
artcl_titl_en: Inter-Korean Basketball for 22:00 - the First Match-up#Inter-Korean Basketball - the First Match-up#

artcl_ctt:
For the first time in nearly a decade... the two Koreas are up against each other to shoot ball.
First up in the two-day basketball friendlies... a chance for both the North and South Korean players to get to know each other through a mixed matchup.

? There''s a new item that promotes privacy.
It''s a portable gadget which detects wire taps or ?hidden cameras within a radius of five meters.
Spy Capture sends off an alarm when it detects cordless electronic signals and helps users locate a bug in the surroundings.
Y-L Datasystems says a patent in pending for the product and it is negotiating with potential buyers in Japan, China, Singapore, and Hong Kong.
Measuring four by eight centimeters and weighing 40 grams, Spy Capture has an extensive frequency range to detect all kinds of bugs and hidden cameras which use frequencies from 70 to 400 Mega Hertz.?

artcl_ctt:
?These games in Seoul are being called a milestone for inter-Korean ties.
That the North Koreans are here... is itself a rare break from the past.
More on what the exchange means... in this report by Park Jonghong.

? The holding of the inter-Korean games carries significance because it was not politically motivated.
As a natural course of development, analysts say with increased economic exchange between the two Koreas came this latest sports exchange.
This group of North Korean athletes came to Seoul for the first time since 19-90 when soccer players crossed the border.
Until recently all North Korean visits to the South had been governed by the two administrations.
But as Hyundai''s cruise tours to Mount Kumkang picked up steam so did personnel exchange to promote economic activities and sports.
Some are optimistic the visit by North Korean basketball players have opened the way for more South Korean businessmen to invite their North Korean partners and technicians to Seoul.
Other experts say the visit and the friendly matches combining athletes from both the South and the North in a single team is a gesture to ease tensions on the peninsula.
They say Pyongyang is trying to create a favorable atmosphere to better its relations with Washington and Tokyo.
?This especially after its pledge to Washington in September that it would halt missile tests ... and Japan''s recent lifting of economic sanctions on the communist country.
Most analysts agree the basketball exchange will not merely end on the court but spur future economic exchange and help the isolated North Korean residents better understand South Korea.
This is Park Jonghong Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: The meaning of Inter-Korean Basketball#First day of games#
artcl_titl_en: The meaning of Inter-Korean Basketball#First day of games#

artcl_ctt:
< 베일벗은 우뢰팀 예상외로 막강전력 > 
    (서울=연합뉴스) 문관현기자 = 통일농구대회에 참가하는 북한 남자농구팀 `우뢰''의 전력이 예상보다 막강해 24일 현대-기아 연합팀의 고전이 예상되고 있다.

    대표선수가 4명이나 포함된 우뢰팀은 23일 오전9시 40분부터 잠실체육관에서 농구연습시간을 가졌는데 대부분 체력과 탄력이 뛰어난데다 취약점으로 지적된 외곽슛도 예상보다 위력적이었다.

    선수들은 가볍게 몸을 푼 뒤 가진 슈팅연습시간에 세계최장신 센터 이명훈(30.235㎝)을 비롯 센터 조광연(29.194㎝), 포워드  박천종(30.186㎝).박인철(27.187㎝), 가드 박경남(27.182㎝).이영범(30.182㎝) 등이 3점슛 라인밖에서도 슛을 대부분  적중시켰다.

    이명훈은 내외곽을 넘나들며 슛을 시도했는데 신장을 이용한 레이업슛은 물론 3점슛까지 자유자재로 구사하는 골감각을 과시해 현대 -기아연합팀 관계자들을  긴장시켰다.

    북한의 마이클조던으로 불리는 박천종역시 고무공같은 탄력을 지녔고 넘치는 힘을 바탕으로 과감한 돌파도 수차례 선보였으며 외곽슛과 자유투 모두 림을 통과시켰다.

    특히 이영범은 코치의 지도아래 혼자서 집중적으로 3점슛을 시도했는데  10여차례 시도한 볼이 모두 그물을 흔들어 취재진과 교예단으로부터 박수갈채를 받기도 했다.

    이들은 개인기 연습보다는 팀훈련을 집중적으로 연습했는데 장기간  평양시체육단 농구팀에서 한솥밥을 먹던 선수출신이기때문에 `눈빛만 봐도 무엇을 원하는지 안다''고 말할 사이로 팀웍이 뛰어나다는 평이다.

    우뢰팀은 이날 연습으로 미뤄 △이명훈을 센터로 내세운 골밑 플레이 △상대 선수들이 이명훈을 견제하는 사이 박천종을 이용한 골밑 플레이  △속공  △중.장거리 슛 등 다양한 공격을 펼칠 것으로 보인다.

    특히  가드 이영범, 포워드 박천종.박인철 등은 중.장거리 슛도 잘 쏘는 것으로 알려져 `우뢰''팀은 전술 운영에서  이들을 적절히 활용할 것으로 비쳐졌다..

통일농구 북측방문단 서울 도착(종합) 
    (서울=연합뉴스) 박운영기자 = 23일부터 이틀간 펼쳐질 통일농구경기에  참석할 북측방문단이 22일 서울에 왔다.

    송호경 조선아시아태평양평화위원회 부위원장을 단장으로 한 북측방문단은 이날 오후 3시10분 중국민항 전세기편으로 김포공항에 도착했다.

    북한 체육선수단의 서울 방문은 지난 90년 10월 서울에서 열렸던  통일축구대회에 9년만이다.

    지난 9월 평양 대회에 이어 두번째로 열리는 이번 경기는 남북한 경제협력 뿐만 아니라 남북한 화해무드 조성에 크게 기여할 것으로 기대된다.

    북측 방문단은 중국민항 전세기편으로 중국 베이징(北京)을 거쳐 김포공항에 도착한후 정몽헌(鄭夢憲) 현대 회장 등 현대 관계자들이 마련한 환영행사에 참석했다.

    정 회장은 환영사에서 ''통일농구대회가 서울에서 다시 열리게 된 것은 남북체육교류의 새로운 시작이자 남북신뢰 회복의 중요한 계기가 될 것''이라고 말했다.

    북측 방문단은 송호경 조선아시아태평양평화위원회(아태) 부위원장 등 아태  관계자 8명, 벼락(남자) 회오리(여자) 농구선수단 38명, 교예공연단 14명, TV중계요원 2명 등 62명이다.

    송 부위원장 등 아태 관계자들은 환영식후 곧바로 종로구 계동 현대사옥으로 이동, 오후 5시부터 30분간 정주영(鄭周永) 현대 명예회장과 면담한뒤 숙소인  워커힐호텔로 이동했다.

    세계 최장신 농구선수인 리명훈 선수를 비롯한 북한측 선수단과 공연단은  잠실실내체육관 답사를 마치고 워커힐호텔로 옮겼다.

    북측 방문단은 오후 7시30분부터는 워커힐호텔 무궁화그랜드볼룸에서  현대측이 베푼 환영만찬에 참석했다.

    선수단은 23일 오전에는 잠실보조체육관에서 연습을 한후 오후 2시30분부터  혼합팀 여자경기, 혼합팀 남자경기을 가지며 24일에는 오전 연습후 오후  2시30분부터 여자, 남자순으로 남북 대항전을 펼칠 예정이다.

    북한측은 이번 대회기간중 세계적 수준인 평양교예단을 파견, 양일간  여자경기와 남자경기 사이에 20분씩 경축공연을 펼치고 모든 경기를 위성을 통해 북한  전역에 TV로 생중계할 예정이다.

    북측 방문단은 24일 오후 8시5분부터 서울 하얏트호텔 그랜드볼룸에서 현대측에 답례만찬을 베푼뒤 25일 오전 9시50분 돌아간다.

    현대와 북한측은 이 대회를 정례화하고 경기종목수도 늘려 나갈 계획이다.

[통일농구대회] 선수단 62명 입국…혼합팀 대결 
세계최장신 선수 리명훈(30．2m35)과 북한 여자농구의 간판 리명화(27．1m72)가 포함된 북한 농구선수단이 처음으로 한국땅을 밟았다. 

남북 통일농구대회에 참가하는 북한선수단은 22일 오후 3시5분 중국민항편으로 김포공항에 도착했다. 

지난 90년 남북통일축구대회 이후 9년만의 북한 스포츠선수단 한국방문. 

송호경 조선아태평화위원회 부위원장을 단장으로 구성된 62명의 남녀 선수단은 3박4일 일정으로 서울에 머물며 혼합팀전(23일)과 남북대결(24일) 등 2차례 경기를 갖는다. 

북한의 남녀 최강팀 `우뢰''와 `회오리''에 남자 현대－기아 연합팀과 여자 현대산업개발팀이 각각 맞선다. 

지난 9월 현대－기아 연합팀의 평양대회 참가에 대한 답방 형식으로 서울을 찾은 북한선수단은 남자 출전팀을 `벼락''에서 사실상 대표팀인 `회오리''로 전격 교체하는 등 대회 2연속 승리에 강한 집착을 보이고 있다. 

또 이번 대회에서는 세계적인 수준을 자랑하는 평양교예단의 서커스 공연도 함께 펼쳐져 관심을 모으고 있다.

? A joint project to develop semiconductor technology will be launched early next year.
? Seven companies from Korea, the U-S, Japan and Germany will form a consortium to do research on next generation D-RAM computer chips.
The D-RAM, which stands for dynamic random access memory... is the market mainstay.
Researchers are reportedly aiming to have the new chips ready for production lines by the year 2002.
Korea''s Samsung and Hyundai Electronics...  and Micron Technology and Intel from the U-S ... as well as Infineon Technologies of Germany and Japan''s N-E-C and Hitachi will take part in the multinational consortium.
These industry leaders produce approximately 80-percent of the world''s D-RAM chip supply.?
artcl_titl: 반도체 공동개발#Consortium to develop DRAM chips#
artcl_titl_en: 반도체 공동개발#Consortium to develop DRAM chips#

artcl_ctt:
?

? This year''s Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to a group of volunteer doctors... known in English as Doctors Without Borders.
The group dispatches some 25-hundred medical professionals every year to work in 80-countries.
They were praised by the Nobel committee for working under difficult circumstances... often putting their lives at risk... in some of the world''s most dangerous hot spots.

Doctors Without Borders... like so many nongovernmental organizations or N-G-O''s... focuses on humanitarian rather than commercial objectives.
N-G-Os are non-profit, voluntary groups that work for the benefit or welfare of the community... as small as grass roots "on my own doorstep" activities... or on a larger scale, striving for environmental protection like Greenpeace or human rights, like Amnesty.



Oh JiWon Arirang TV.?

?In other news... Seoul''s Commerce, Industry and Energy Minister, Chung Duck-Koo said yesterday...? the government will take legal action against union members of Korea Heavy Industries and Construction or Hanjung(한중).
This announcement comes after General Electric of the U-S cancelled a 2-million dollar order, earlier in the week.
G-E says... Hanjung might not be able to meet its delivery date due to the on-going labor troubles.
Union workers have been on strike for more than a month... protesting the planned privatization of the state-run company.
?
artcl_titl: Court accepts management plea to restrict strikes at Hanjung
artcl_titl_en: Court accepts management plea to restrict strikes at Hanjung

artcl_ctt:
?Global spending on Information and Technology reached 758-billion dollars last year... which is up by 6-point-2 percent from 19-97.
?According to a study by International Data Corporation... world spending on I-T is expected to reach 1-trillion dollars by 2002.
Currently, the global I-T market is posting a solid growth... due to the stabilization of troubled economies around the world and a rebound in the personal computer and server markets.
Continued growth in the software and services markets are also cited as reasons. 
?
artcl_titl: Global spending on IT to reach $1 tril. in 2002
artcl_titl_en: Global spending on IT to reach $1 tril. in 2002

artcl_ctt:
?North Korean basketball players were in Seoul this week... for a series of friendly matches... both with and against South Korean teams.
The games continued a revival this year in inter-Korean sports exchanges.
We see more in this report.
? For the first time in nine-years... the two Koreas met face-to-face in Seoul... putting aside their different ideolgies for the sake of sportsmanship.
The event comes amid better economic ties between the rival Koreas... with the South''s largest conglomerate Hyundai spearheading the way for greater exchanges.
In the first of the two-day basketball friendlies... North and South Korean athletes got a chance to know each other better... regrouped into mixed teams.
One definite star... was Ri Myung-hoon... the world''s tallest player... looking almighty in all his 7-foot-9... or 2-point-35-meters height.
Ri''s team Tankeul(단결) or "Solidarity"...  lost to Tanhap(단합)... or "Unity" by a slight margin.
But Ri proved he not only outstood others in size but skill... earning Tankeul... 24-points.
Another attraction was the acrobatic troop from North Korea.
Tens of thousands of fans oohed... and aahed... every time they did their mega-twists and turns.
?? "The game... which is a follow-up to a September match in the communist North... will be the last in a decade of sports exchanges that have yielded mixed results at best."
Nonetheless... the 12-thousand spectators packed into Seoul''s Chamsil Olympic Stadium put aside their political opinions.
While the older generation stressed the significance of the games... 
?? "We''ve always wanted to see unification through sports exchanges... I can''t believe it''s happening today."
Most of the younger crowds said it just felt great.
? 
?  
And... some appeared to be more interested in the fact North Koreans were here in the South.
?	?
 "I want the South to win." 
(comment) But it''s a mixed group today...
But regardless of whose side they were on... the excitement was evident.
?
?  "Quite happy to see there''s communication going on between the two Koreas. Very pleased."
On Christmas Eve... the two Koreas faced off each other... for a game of hoops aimed at stoking goodwill between the longtime rivals.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?

? Teams from North Korea will arrive today... for two days of basketball games against players from the Hyundai Group starting tommorow.
It''s a follow up to games held in the North 

Here''s more.

?
Basketball games between the North and South Korea will be held for two days starting tommorrow at the Chamsil Olympic Stadium in southern Seoul.


The 62-member North Korean delegation .... including 38 male and female basketball players will arrive today... flying in from Beijing.
The North Korean team will include the world''s tallest known basketball player... Ri Myung-hoon... who is 7-foot-9 or about 2-point-35 meters tall.
The Pyongyang team will be facing off against South Korean teams from the Hyundai Group ... which is trying to expand it''s business in the North.
Top officials from the sports delegation are scheduled to meet with Hyundai founder Chung Ju-young today... to discuss further the further expansion of such exchanges.?

?On a more serious note.
There''ve been some ? Korean contributions to the field of medicine.
First... a test-kit that takes just 3 minutes... to detect infection of HIV... the virus that causes AIDS.
Developed by Dong-A Pharmaceutical... the process involves taking just one or two drops of blood... to get a quick and accurate result... seen by the naked eye.
Till now... testing had been through a pricey method called ELISA.
ELISA also took around 3 hours to produce results.
Dong-A''s new item will hit the market next month.?

?Meanwhile... in Seoul back on Tuesday.
Masayoshi Son... Internet mogul... and founder of Japan''s Softbank Corporation... announced details of a major project... of investing in Korean firms over the next three years.
This... as he signed a deal to start a joint holding company.
Yon Seong-hun has the story.

?A hundred million dollars to be invested in Korean venture and Internet-related firms over the next three years.
That''s the gist of a plan... announced in Seoul Tuesday... by Masayoshi Son... founder and president of Softbank.
The vehicle for those investments will be a joint holding company... to be launched next month... between Softbank and Naray Corporation.

??"I think in the next century, Korea will play a very important role in the global ?	market for the Internet society to come."

Softbank will hold an 80 percent stake... and Naray... a local mobile communications services provider... will have the rest.
Son says total investments could also rise to as high as 300 million dollars in that time.
The Korean-based firm... called Softbank Holdings Korea... will be among the 12 that run some 140 companies worldwide.
It''s an empire that includes major stakes in big Internet names like Yahoo!, Yahoo! Japan, E-Trade and Geocities.
Softbank also recently set up Internet-based stock trading platforms... called Nasdaq Japan and Europe... to be integrated with the U-S Nasdaq.

?"We are willing to provide our capability to connect with Nasdaq U-S, Nasdaq Europe, Nasdaq Japan, and possibliiy some kind of partnership with the Korean stock market... [it] . might be a possiblity."

A second-generation Korean-Japanese... with a vision for the Internet and the homeland.
Yon Seong-hun, Arirang T-V.?
artcl_titl: KTW Softbank to Invest $100 mln in Korea
artcl_titl_en: KTW Softbank to Invest $100 mln in Korea

artcl_ctt:
? He set out studying medicine to heal the human body... 
but... ended up saving computers from deadly viruses.
We''re talking about Ahn Chul-soo... the man behind Korea''s first computer vaccine program... who now is the undisputed leader in Korea''s anti-virus program market.
Arirang TV''s Ahn Chak-hee met with the doctor to talk about the Y2K bug and other related matters.

?
? "Could you tell us more about what you think about this Y2K problem?"

? "The Y2K virus is just a small part of the Y2K problem and I don''t think the virus is going to create a big problem. But looking at the news reports these days there''s more concern over the Y2K virus than the Y2K problem itself and I think there''s a lot of misinformation about the virus.
From the standpoint of vaccine experts like us, we have to be prepared for the slightest problem and we plan to go into emergency alert but I don''t feel that we have to instill a terror among ordinary users."

"What comes after the Y2K virus? Are there other montrous viruses in the new millemnnium that we should be watching out for?"

"There are far more serious viruses than the Y2K virus. One of the most deadly is the CIH virus which struck this year on April 26th when hundreds of thousands of computers were destroyed. There is a very high likelihood that it will strike again next year. The Y2K virus will likely pass without causing too much damage but a great deal of damage is possible on April 26th next year. For us that is more serious than the Y2K virus and we''re already preparing for that."

"Are there plans for your company to expand overseas?"

"Our company became the second in Korea after Hangul and Computer to total 10-billion won in sales. To keep up the growth we think it is a must for us to expand abroad next year. So of course we''ll work to keep our number one position at home and continue our efforts to grow but we''ll also focus on foreign markets next year."

"In the case of the US market we have a joint company and we plan to enter the US market via that company. As for the Chinese market, the vaccine market there is in its initial stages and we think we can enter the market with our technology and we''ll approach the market with our product directly."?

? And... foreigners who had the foresight to invest in Korean stocks this year... reaped huge profits.
? The Finance-Economy Ministry says... on average... foreign investors saw a near three-fold return on their investment.
As of Tuesday... stock holdings by overseas investors... amounted to 63 billion dollars... up 42 billion from the same time last year.
Even taking into account their net fund inflow this year of 4 and-a-half billion... the market capitalization figure still increased by more than 37-billion dollars.
The Ministry attributes the gains to strong performances by bluechips, the favorite among foreign investors... and to the stronger Korean won.?

artcl_titl_en: #Foreign Investors Reap Profits in Local Bourse#

? We begin today... with a message urging national unity.
Marking the second anniversary of winning the country''s top job... President Kim Dae-jung this week, assessed his time in office and looked into the new millennium.
Here''s what the chief executive had to say.

? Dressed in casual wear... President Kim reflected on the past year... and talked about what lies ahead for the future of the country.
For the first time ever... the interview was held in the living quarters of Chongwadae.
The chief executive said political stability is the key to prosperity in the 21st century... and stressed the need to root out regionalism and corruption.
Turning to inter-Korean relations...
the president predicted there would be greater changes than expected in the coming year.
Another topic that surfaced was the economy... which has made a dramatic turnaround over the past two years.
But, Kim stressed that a lot of work still remains to be done.
? "We have overcome the crisis, but now we have to prepare for new challenges.  Failure to do so will lead to ? another crisis."
Finally, the chief executive stressed the importance of a united effort...
He said he is responsible for running state affairs...
But urged everyone to pitch in... to make greater strides in the new millennium.?

artcl_titl_en: KTW Fireside Chat with the President

?Meanwhile... a team of Korean doctors has developed an oriental herbal medicine... that may help suppress cancer cells from spreading... and also prevent relapse after surgery.
The new drug''s called Hangamdan(항암단).
And it''s made up nine herbal ingredients.
The team works out of the Taejon University Oriental Hospital Cancer Center... and is led by Cho Jong-kwan (조종관).
Cho says... so far the medicine has been tested on 320 cancer patients for about a year and a half.?

? A clear indication of how computers are rapidly making their place into young people''s everyday lives.
A recent survey found college students are spending most of their spare time on the computer... to chat... play games and surf the net.
Cho Heemyung has more.

? What do college students do during their spare time?
A collegian publication recently polled more than 700-undergrads in Seoul and found 23-percent of them spent their free time on the computer... to chat... play games or browse the net.
As "Campus Journal" says trailing behind in distant second and third choices were reading books... and watching movies.
Only about 2-percent of the respondents said they make use of their free time... to study or catch up on missed assignments.
As for their efforts on personal development... one-third said they were either learning English and other foreign languages... or studying to earn a special license.
Looking at their spending habits... more than half of the students said their monthly spending allowance hovered around 110-to-300 thousand won... with the main source of income being none other than their own parents.
Cho Heemyung... Arirang TV.?

? 1999.....
It was an embarrassing year in Korean politics.... marred with a series of accusations, denials and revelations...both from the ruling and opposition camps.
One scandal that stands out is the so-called "furgate"....implicating a number of senior government officials....their wives and a business tycoon and his spouse.
The incident characterized as a failed lobbying attempt by the bankrupt Shindong-A Group...... led to the arrest of former Prosecutor-general Kim Tae-jung.... who allegedly tried to cover up his wife''s involvement.
It was firts time in the nation''s history that the prosecution had to arrest its chief prosecutor.
President Kim Dae-jung.... who saw his ruling party''s popularity plunge in the wake of the scandal....offered an apology to the nation.
To put the past behind... and start the new millennium on a fresh note...
President Kim proposed the creation of a new political party... a party that will be launched this coming January.
He hopes the move will help the ruling camp win back voter support... in time for next April''s general election.
Speaking at a ceremony to launch the new party''s preparatory committee ..... the President envisioned the new party to be a pillar of political stability.
The party''s major principles... Kim said...should be democracy... market economy... and welfare.
And one of its main tasks...rooting out regionalism... once and for all.
Not to be outdone....the opposition Grand National Party has also set up a special committee....to revamp its structure and prepare for the challenges of the future.
Throughout the year... the two rival camps continued their efforts to restructure the political sector.
They are now working to revise current election system.
Both sides hope that political reform... will turn around public sentiment... at a time when voter apathy is at its peak.?

? As the end of the year draws near... rising worries around the world... about the possibility of a computer meltdown triggered by the millennium bug.
? That''s when the date switches to January first, 2000... some older computers reading only the last two digits... could mistake it for the year 1900.
Countries around the world have been preparing for the Y2K glitch... with the cost of efforts estimated at half a trillion U-S dollars so far.
Industrialized nations have spent the most money... although experts believe the millennium bug poses the greatest risk for developing countries.
Most nations say they expect relatively few problems...
But, people are still taking precautions... stocking up on basic necessities and withdrawing some extra cash.
Several airlines have rescheduled their flights to avoid being in the air on January the first.?

? Beer lovers in Korea... will have a greater range of choices from next year.
? Industry sources say... flavored beer will soon make its debut... its taste... ranging from cherry... to the health root, ginseng.
Manufacturers are currently experimenting with different flavors... hoping to appeal to today''s beer drinkers.
The wider choice follows the Seoul government''s decision to ease beer-making regulations... including those on the use of additives.?

?Cartoons are usually a treat for kids of all ages... and we also mean the young at heart.
Well... there''s a festival that kicked off just outside Seoul recently... celebrating a hundred years of Korean cartoons.
All the colors and characters... in this story by Kim Boram.

? This is the first printed Korean comic strip.
It made its appearance back in 1909 in one of Korea''s earliest newspapers, the Daehan-min Bo.
The 1999 Puchon Comic Animation Festival chronicled the 100 year history of Korean comics.
The Puchon city mayor along with notable guests in the Korean Animation circle were on hand at the ceremonial ribbon cutting to kick off the festivities.
? "Despite the field of animation and 
?comics being an integral part of our culture, it has not been given enough recognition.
The city of Puchon, through this center, hopes to bring comics and cartoons closer to the public as well as help the industry grow."
Held at and sponsored by the Puchon Cartoon Information Center, the festival also represented the Puchon International Students Animation Festival and the Amateur Cartoonists Association.
The festival also focused on the future of Korean animation, displaying 3-D computer animation graphics and virtual reality.
This display sold arts and crafts designed by some of Korea''s most prolific artitsts.
? "I''m here at a display made to resemble an old comic book room.  It allows fans to read and view old Korean comics in their original state."
Over the years, Korean animation made its transition from the comic strip to comic books to animated features.
On display were the many genres of Korean comic books such as historical , political , romance , children''s cartoons and underground comics.
Other events at the festival included screenings of popular animated features and animation instruction.
The five day event, which ran from the eighteenth to the twenty-second of this month, showcased the past, present and future of Korean comics and animation.
Kim Boram... Arirang TV.?

? How do you celebrate Christmas?
With egg-nogs and mistle toe?
Well, the Grand Inter-Continental Hotel in Seoul decided to celebrate the jolly season with traditional Korean rice cakes and kuk-ak.

? Call it what you will... Christmas with a local twist... or Christmas that harmonizes the sounds of the east and west...

How about this gigantic millennium rice cake... stretching 3-meters long?

Young musicians busy doing their last minute tuning for what appears to be the first performance of Christmas carols on traditional Korean instruments...

?? "Here in Korea, we''ve decided to invite an orchestra of young children to perform in the lobby and celebrate with rice cake which is part of the Korean tradition."

The melody sounds all too familiar... yet it''s hard to not notice the interesting harmony....

As music filled the air... crowds gathered around... intrigued by what they saw.

The mood reached a climax as a group of samulnori performers added a rhythmic beat... 

?? (여자자막) It''s really fun doing carols with Kayakum.
??  (남자 자막) I play Taegum. It was great playing western pieces with my instrument.

There it is...
After the performance... colorful Santas and well-wishers gathered to welcome the year 2000 with a rather interesting... rice-cake cutting ceremony... 

With days numbered until the dawning of a new era... wishful thinking on many people''s mind.
Although it''s too early to tell what the new year will have in store... but one thing''s certain... this century''s last Christmas definitely feels a lot merrier and richer than last year''s.

?President Kim and Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil... last night... decided not to merge the two ruling coalition parties.
??The two being the National Congress for New Politics... and the United Liberal Democrats.
The two men met earlier in the day... when the Prime Minister briefed the President on his recent South American trip.
And also ... during a Chongwadae dinner for ruling coalition officials.
The President reportedly decided to respect the Prime Minister''s argument... that given the situation within the ULD... a coalition government would be more appropriate.?

? So says an official with the Finance-Economy Ministry... who added the government will overhaul existing policies... to facilitate mergers and acquisitions... and simplify laws related to bankruptcy cases.
The official''s comments are said to reflect the Ministry''s plans for the year 2000... expected to be unveiled early next month.
Authorities will also urge financial institutions to implement stricter guidelines when giving out loans.
And... no more public funds will be injected into ailing firms... the fate of which will be left entirely to the workings of the market.?

The VP expects to see an open debate over the sale of Daewoo Motor...
But he says  a final deal may not come... until after next April''s general elections... if negotiations drag on for a long time.
G-M reportedly has offered to pay up to seven-trillion won for Daewoo Motor...
It may also buy a third of the creditors'' stake in the local carmaker.?

? Compared to the start of this century... the world has become a much more democratic place.
That''s according to a report released by the pro-democracy group, Freedom House... which points out, however... South and North Korea are two extremes... when it comes to political rights and civil liberties.
Here''s a closer look.

? The 20th century has been dubbed as the democracy''s century.
Wrapping up the past 100 years Freedom House published a special report... tracing the global shift towards democracy.
At the start of the century in 1900 not a single nation gave universal voting rights to its people.
? But... now things have changed and even long-resistant Islamic countries seem to be moving towards democracy.
44 percent of the world this year is classified as totally free... where people enjoy a broad range of political rights and civil liberties.?
Among them... South Korea... scoring two on a scale of one through seven... where seven is considered as NOT free.
Seven is what the communist North Korea got this year... as it did last year.
Other countries with the lowest ratings were Afghanistan and Myanmar.
As for the nations enjoying the greatest amount of freedom... the United States, Switzerland and Sweden.
In terms of population... 2-point-3 billion people or 39 percent live in democratic societies... while 2-point-1 billion or 36 percent live under strict government control.?

? Good Morning.
Today is Wednesday, December twenty-second, 19-99.
After days of record low bone-chilling conditions... today... Korea will get to see above zero degrees before the day is over.
In the meantime... this morning... we are still seeing freezing temperatures... but they are higher than yesterday...
Seoul is at minus seven degrees Celsius.
Mostly mild conditions are expected.?

? Seoul''s top financial regulators are moving to revise the current market rules on initial public offerings... to better protect the rights of retail investors.
? The Financial Supervisory Service plans to penalize institutions who fail to fulfill their promises of applying for I-P-Os ... by banning such companies from buying any new issues for about a year.
Eight of the fifteen companies that debuted since May... have seen their stocks fall below the listing price.
The new rules would also call for the underwriter of I-P-Os to buy back a certain amount of the new issues... should the prices be lower than when they were first listed.?

( 북한전 )-late September

North South Basketball Matches Kick Off 

The "Unification Basketball Tournament" held in Pyongyang on Tuesday will be an event to be remembered for a variety of reasons. Attended by almost 20,000 Pyongyang men and women in their thirties and forties, most sports fans in attendance wore dark colored suits or hanboks, making the crowd look as if it were ready for Chusok. For athletes from the south, there was a noticeable absence of the usual hundreds of teenage girls yelling their favorite male players names, and instead what was mostly heard was the singing of popular North Korean songs such as "Whistling Along" and "Glad To Meet You." The day''s events were the first ever to be broadcast live south of the DMZ, via a satellite signal sent through a dish from Thailand. 


Winning seemed to matter to few in attendance, since the athletes from North and South were not on separate teams. Teams were instead formed from the athletes from both countries, who were still readily identifiable by their strikingly different hair styles. Some were even able to tell the difference by the way the athletes played, with one commentator from SBS saying that the way the North Korean women played reminded him of Korean basketball in the seventies, with fast, organized movement and two handed shots. Wednesday will see the teams from the North play each other rounding off the tournament. 

NK Wins Friendly Basketball Matches 
A North Korean all-star women''s basketball team dubbed '' Whirlwind'' beat Hyundai 95-93 following two dubious decisions by the North Korean referee Wednesday. With twenty seconds remaining, the score was tied and Hyundai had the ball, when the official called a foul despite no obvious contact. Whirlwind duly scored and with six seconds to play Hyundai blitzed their opponents and scored a three point basket. The referee, however, promptly disallowed the score saying that time was out. The Hyundai team didn''t bother to protest and merely returned to their seats smiling. 

North Korea''s male team ''Thunderers'', however, won a indisputable match over Hyundai by 102-71. Hyundai players will return to Seoul Friday by way of Beijing. 

현대‘이명훈의 우뢰팀’이길까



경향신문 [ 해외 ] 1999. 12. 21. 火


이번엔 이길수 있을까. 지난 9월 평양대회의 동반패배는 `대북 서비스''. 아무리 통일농구대회라고 해도 안방에서 지고 싶지는 않은 법. 22일 서울에 오는 북한 남녀농구단을 맞이하는 현대 남매팀이 필승의지를 불태우고 있다. 

평양대회때의 `예정된 패배''를 이번엔 `예상을 뒤엎은 승리''로 설욕하고 싶은 것. 그러나 과연 쉽게 이길수 있을지 의문이다. 

특히 세계최장신센터 이명훈(2ｍ35)이 포함된 북한 `우뢰''를 상대할 현대 걸리버스는 닥친 싸움을 어떻게 넘길지 걱정이 태산같다. 

상대가 해볼만한 `벼락''에서 사실상 북한대표팀인 `우뢰''로 전격 변경된 게 신선우감독과 선수들의 부담을 가중시키고 있다. 

24일에 열릴 남북 단일팀의 남자대항전은 이번 서울대회의 하이라이트. 남한 프로농구의 챔피언 현대와 북한의 `공훈체육인'' 이명훈 박천종이 소속한 우뢰의 맞대결은 세계언론의 관심마저 끌고 있다. 

신선우감독은 현재 `높이의 절대열세''를 전제하고 전략을 짜고 있다. 

일단 국내포인트가드의 쌍벽인 이상민-강동희를 활용한 속공과 조성원 추승균의 외곽포로 승부를 걸 작정이다. 

이명훈에 대한 수비대책은 `인해전술''. 신인 정훈종(2ｍ5·중앙대)과 구본근(1ｍ97), 기아에서 수혈받은 김동언(1ｍ97)을 번갈아 투입, 이명훈을 피곤하게 만든다는 전략. 여자단일팀 대항전은 현대산업의 승산이 높은 편이다. 

현대는 지난 평양대회에서 느슨한 플레이를 펼치고도 회오리에 93-95, 2점차이로 졌다. 

내년 현대건설로 소속팀 변경을 앞둔 현대산업은 최근 진성호감독이 재신임을 받고 전주원도 연봉협상을 끝내 팀분위기가 살아났다. 

북한전 승리를 새팀으로 탄생할 계기로 삼고 있다.


SBS가 23일과 24일 잠실 실내체육관에서 벌어지는 ''통일농구대회''를 단독 생중계한다. 

이번 통일농구대회에 참가하는 북측 방문단은 아시아·태평양평화위원회 송호경 부위원장을 단장으로 남녀농구 선수단,교예공연단,TV중계인원,아·태평화위 관계자 등 총 62명이며 22일 중국 민항기편으로 베이징을 거쳐 서울에 도착한다. 

23일 오후 3시40분 여자 혼합팀 경기를 시작으로 5시25분에는 남자혼합팀 경기가 펼쳐지고,24일에는 오후 3시부터 여자 대항경기와 남자 대항경기가 연이어 열린다. 

[통일농구] 북한 농구 선수단 공식 일정  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
북한 남녀농구단 62명이 역사적인 통일농구대회에 참가하기 위해 22일 서울에 도착,3박4일간의 공식일정에 들어간다.

북한 남녀농구단은 이날 오전 평양을 출발,베이징을 거쳐 중국 민항 전세기편으로 오후 김포공항에 도착할 예정이다.

아태관계자와 교예단을 포함한 북한 남녀농구단은 공항에서 환영행사에 참석한 뒤 경기장인 잠실실내체육관을 답사하고 숙소인 쉐라톤 워커힐 호텔에 여장을 풀며 서울의 첫날밤을 맞는다.

북한 남녀농구단은 23일 오후 2시30분부터 현대 남녀팀과 혼합경기를 가진 뒤 이어 24일 오후 2시30분부터는 쌍방 대항경기를 갖는다.

지난 9월 평양경기에 이어 답방형식으로 열리는 이번 서울경기에 참가하는 북한농구팀은 남자는 세계 최장신센터 이명훈(235㎝)이 포함된 사실상의 대표팀인 ‘우뢰팀’이,여자는 ‘회오리팀’이 각각 출전한다.

북한 남녀농구단은 3박4일간의 공식일정을 마치고 25일 오전 김포공항을 통해 출국할 예정이다.

통일농구 북측방문단 서울 도착(종합) 
    (서울=연합뉴스) 박운영기자 = 23일부터 이틀간 펼쳐질 통일농구경기에  참석할 북측방문단이 22일 서울에 왔다.

    송호경 조선아시아태평양평화위원회 부위원장을 단장으로 한 북측방문단은 이날 오후 3시10분 중국민항 전세기편으로 김포공항에 도착했다.

    북한 체육선수단의 서울 방문은 지난 90년 10월 서울에서 열렸던  통일축구대회에 9년만이다.

    지난 9월 평양 대회에 이어 두번째로 열리는 이번 경기는 남북한 경제협력 뿐만 아니라 남북한 화해무드 조성에 크게 기여할 것으로 기대된다.

    북측 방문단은 중국민항 전세기편으로 중국 베이징(北京)을 거쳐 김포공항에 도착한후 정몽헌(鄭夢憲) 현대 회장 등 현대 관계자들이 마련한 환영행사에 참석했다.

    정 회장은 환영사에서 ''통일농구대회가 서울에서 다시 열리게 된 것은 남북체육교류의 새로운 시작이자 남북신뢰 회복의 중요한 계기가 될 것''이라고 말했다.

    북측 방문단은 송호경 조선아시아태평양평화위원회(아태) 부위원장 등 아태  관계자 8명, 벼락(남자) 회오리(여자) 농구선수단 38명, 교예공연단 14명, TV중계요원 2명 등 62명이다.

    송 부위원장 등 아태 관계자들은 환영식후 곧바로 종로구 계동 현대사옥으로 이동, 오후 5시부터 30분간 정주영(鄭周永) 현대 명예회장과 면담한뒤 숙소인  워커힐호텔로 이동했다.

    세계 최장신 농구선수인 리명훈 선수를 비롯한 북한측 선수단과 공연단은  잠실실내체육관 답사를 마치고 워커힐호텔로 옮겼다.

    북측 방문단은 오후 7시30분부터는 워커힐호텔 무궁화그랜드볼룸에서  현대측이 베푼 환영만찬에 참석했다.

    선수단은 23일 오전에는 잠실보조체육관에서 연습을 한후 오후 2시30분부터  혼합팀 여자경기, 혼합팀 남자경기을 가지며 24일에는 오전 연습후 오후  2시30분부터 여자, 남자순으로 남북 대항전을 펼칠 예정이다.

    북한측은 이번 대회기간중 세계적 수준인 평양교예단을 파견, 양일간  여자경기와 남자경기 사이에 20분씩 경축공연을 펼치고 모든 경기를 위성을 통해 북한  전역에 TV로 생중계할 예정이다.

    북측 방문단은 24일 오후 8시5분부터 서울 하얏트호텔 그랜드볼룸에서 현대측에 답례만찬을 베푼뒤 25일 오전 9시50분 돌아간다.

    현대와 북한측은 이 대회를 정례화하고 경기종목수도 늘려 나갈 계획이다.

? The number of jobless Koreans dropped below the 1-million mark last month... for the first time in 22 months.
?The National Statistical Office says... November''s unemployment rate was 4-point-4 percent... translating to some 970-thousand people out of a job.
Compared to November of last year... the improvement is by 2-point-8 percentage points.
The N-S-O says most sectors hired more people...  except agriculture, forestry and fisheries.
Meanwhile... under OECD standards... the rate was slightly higher at 4-point-7 percent... just over a million jobless.?

? Korea''s first multipurpose satellite... KOMPSAT... or Arirang-one... made its first contact with the Taejon groundstation... early this morning.
As an Earth-science spacecraft... KOMPSAT will serve this country in several specific applications.
We learn what they are... in our next report.

? KOMPSAT-one is currently in orbit 685 kilometers above the Earth... at a speed of 6-point-6 kilometers per second.
The satellite blasted off into space from California''s Vandenburg Air Force Base....Tuesday.
After liftoff... it sent its first signals to groundstations in the South Pole and Germany.
KOMPSAT''s first contact with a Korean base came at 27 minutes after midnight, local time... as it transmitted signals to the groundstation in Taejon... the site of the Korea Aerospace Research Institute.
The spacecraft will make four to six contacts a day with Taejon.
KOMPSAT, which stands for Korean Multipurpose Satellite... is the centerpiece project of Korea''s space program.
Its main mission... utilizing high-tech equipment to map Korean territory, monitor ocean color, movements and other earth resources... as well as perform various scientific experiments in space.
KOMPSAT, or Arirang One, is the first satellite that was made with the participation of Korean scientists... from its inception to the final production.
The satellite will orbit the earth 14-to-15 times a day for three years.?

? Firm overnight gains on Wall Street are credited with boosting investor sentiment on the local stock exchange.
? The benchmark KOSPI managed to recover the 960 level... rising 9 points... to 967-point-83.
Program buying also helped the index bounce back from its earlier low near the 940 mark.
Foreign investors continued to buy... picking up nearly 66 billion won''s worth of shares...
But institutional players and individuals were in the mood to sell... taking the number of decliners to more than three-fold the advancers.
21 issues hit their daily limit highs...
19 sank to their lows... including Taegu City Gas.... making its first appearance on the market today.

A closer look now... at some of the major stocks.?

?A heavier financial load on Korean households... from next month...
Gas prices are going up by about seven percent... the second rise... in 3 months.
Here''s the story.

? Just two months ago, city gas prices went up seven percent.
But already another hike is in the works.
Starting January next year, the Korea Gas Corporation says ?its gas supply price to the country''s 30 local providers will be raised 20-and a half won for every cubic meters.
That''s an increase of about seven-point-one percent.?
The Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry and KOGAS say the projected hike is inevitable given the surge of crude oil prices and gas-producing costs in the last quarter of this year.
? Meanwhile, the nation''s households will subsequently be affected by the price hike.
They currently pay an average of 430 won per cubic meters of city gas used for cooking.
Seoul residents are found to be paying less for gas used in both cooking and central heating, enjoying cheaper rates compared to residents in Iksan and Kwangju.?
A KOGAS official says local city gas providers will soon decide on their price hike margins and adds the capital Seoul will come under a bigger hike than other regions.?
artcl_titl: City Gas Price Hike#January hike of city gas#

?Despite Seoul''s efforts toward continued inter-Korean dialogue... the first vice ministerial level talks between the two sides in more than a year... broke down this summer... failing to produce any tangible results.
Tensions escalated when the naval forces of the two countries clashed in the West Sea after North Korean military ships invaded the buffer zone back in June.
Pyongyang seemed to be further isolating itself from the world with its nuclear and missile threats.
However... inter-Korean relations got a boost from Washington''s point man on North Korea, William Perry... who drew up a new comprehensive approach in dealing with the communist state.
During the Berlin meeting between the United States and North Korea in September... the two signed a landmark deal that could pave the way for peace and security on the Korean Peninsula.
Pyongyang had agreed to halt its missile tests in return for Washington''s lifting of economic sanctions against the communist regime.
Despite political differences... economic cooperation between the two Koreas has improved considerably.
It''s been a little over a year since the first cruise ship departed for North Korea''s Kumgang Mountains... but the number of tourists who''ve been to the Diamond Mountains is estimated to be around 150-thousand since the tours began.
However, the project, like many other aspects of inter-Korean relations has had its share of ups and downs.
Earlier in the summer... the cruise tours came to a halt after a South Korean tourist was detained in the North for allegedly trying to lure a North Korean tour guide to defect.
The tours resumed after more than a month of suspension.
But observers say... Hyundai''s project has served as a catalyst... in stimulating inter-Korean economic cooperation.
The Hyundai Group is planning on building an industrial complex in the North and even South Korea''s small to medium sized companies are looking to do business in the North... which has an abundant supply of cheap labor.
Seoul''s Unification Ministry says... processing on commission trade is expected to hit a record 100 million dollars this year... a ten-fold increase from 19-94.
In the first nine months of this year, inter-Korean trade amounted to more than 885-thousand tons... a 128-percent jump from last year''s figure.
In other areas... a rare break from the past... as athletes from the two sides gathered for soccer and basketball games.
And on the cultural front... North and South Korean singers got together in Pyongyang for a joint performance.
Sohn Jong-hyun, Arirang T-V.?

? North Korea and Japan will meet again some time early next year... for further talks on normalizing ties.
? That was about all they could agree on... during their two-day preliminary meeting in Beijing, China.
Officials from the two sides were reportedly unable to work out their differences over some key issues... like the alleged kidnapping of Japanese citizens by North Korean agents... Pyongyang''s missile program... and Tokyo''s resumption of food aid to the communist state.
The Japanese government expects up to 2 more preliminary sessions... before it can begin talks with the North... on an ambassadorial level.?

? Months-long speculation on whether the ruling coalition partners will merge... could be settled today... ? when President Kim Dae-jung meets Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil.
The Premier just yesterday returned from his two-week trip to South America.
During today''s talks... the two are expected to finalize their positions on the merger proposal...
Observers believe President Kim will push for the marriage... as he believes it to be the ONLY way for the ruling camp to secure a solid victory in next April''s general elections.
But... the prime minister has rejected the idea... saying his United Liberal Democrats party plans to remain a separate entity... while it will continue to cooperate with the National Congress for New Politics.?
artcl_titl: 김대통령 오늘 합당문제 조율#DJ meets JP#
artcl_titl_en: 김대통령 오늘 합당문제 조율#DJ meets JP#

artcl_ctt:
?While there are definite signs of a recovering economy... the truth is... there are also people struggling to make ends meet in Korea.
Well... reporter Oh JiWon has the story about a community service program... that''s making a difference this holiday season.
And it''s about sharing one of life''s most basic needs.

? The Food Bank system operates on a simple principle... reduce hunger by reducing waste.
Businesses donate excess fruits, vegetables, canned goods and other food stuff to local food bank chapters.
Volunteers either pick up the food or connect the donor with families or organizations in need.
? "There are many needy people ever since the IMF crisis.
We are glad to give what little we can to help the homeless, the elderly and orphanges."?
The food bank accepts slightly damaged grocery goods... like dented cans... items that won''t sell but are still too good to throw away.
Most of the time, donations are surplus products that retailers would have returned to their suppliers.
?"This is keeping good food from going to waste.
It also clears unwanted merchandise from store shelves and reduces disposal costs.
In all, it''s a win-win situation for everyone involved."?
Contributions are tax deductible and needless to say, the food is appreciated by many in the community.
The food bank network enables organizations to stretch their limited resources.
?"The donations really help the mothers.
The condiments go a long way in preparing side dishes."
That means other necessities like clothing and medicine can be purchased with the grocery money that is saved.
?  "This is more than simply giving handouts.
Those on the receiving end know there are people who care.
And that fosters a sense of unity."?	
?
According to Mr. Choi, who oversees the food bank program in Seoul, requests for emergency food are higher than ever but donations, unfortunately, lag behind.?

So on a day like this, volunteers from day care centers, nursing homes, and half-way houses are more than happy to load heavy boxes of donated goods.
They all agree it''s the spirit of sharing that helps them through the tough times.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: KTW Donating to Food Bank Network
artcl_titl_en: KTW Donating to Food Bank Network

artcl_ctt:
? 19-99 turned out to be a banner year on the Seoul bourse... with the KOSPI jumping more than 70 percent.
As a result... foreigners in particular, who had the foresight to invest in Korean stocks this year... reaped huge profits.
? According to the Ministry of Finance and Economy... on average... foreign investors saw a near three-fold return on their investment.
As of this past Tuesday... overseas investors'' stock holdings amounted to 63 billion dollars... jumping 42 billion from the same time last year.
Even taking into account their net fund inflow this year of 4-and-a-half billion... market capitalization still increased by almost 40-billion dollars.
The Ministry attributes the gains to stellar performances by bluechips, the favorite among foreign investors... and to the stronger Korean won.?
artcl_titl: KTW Foreign Investors Reap Profits in Local Bourse
artcl_titl_en: KTW Foreign Investors Reap Profits in Local Bourse

artcl_ctt:
?Most stock markets in the world... this year... saw hefty gains... including the KOSPI.
There''s a study out... showing the growth of Seoul''s market was the biggest in Asia... and eighth highest in the world.
Details by Shim Miryung.

? More and more, stock markets around the world are becoming affected by each other... moving up or down... en masse.
19-99 has been a banner year for most exchanges... of the 48 members of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges... or FIBV.. only two recorded losses... Belgium and Ireland.
The Korea Stock Echange recently compared performances of FIBV members over the past year.
Turkey and Finland... saw the biggest gains... their indices soaring 417 percent and 145 percent respectively.
Russia and Brazil... which recorded the biggest LOSSES last year... turned around to take the 3rd and fourth spots.
The tech-heavy Nasdaq... still setting record after record... was at seventh.
And in eighth place... Korea, with a near 72 percent rise.
Among Asian nations though, Korea ranked first... narrowly ahead of Singapore and Indonesia.
Meanwhile... the over-the-counter Kosdaq market ... which is not included in the FIBV... saw a 225 percent jump.
With economies still recovering from the 97 financial crisis.... analysts say next year could well see another bull run for stock markets around the world.
Shim Miryung, Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: KTW Korea''s Bull Run No.1 in Asia
artcl_titl_en: KTW Korea''s Bull Run No.1 in Asia
