Businesses get a tax deduction for their contribution and needless to say, the food is appreciated by many in the community.
The food bank network enables organizations to stretch their limited resources.

?
? North Korean basketball players arrive in Seoul... for 2 days of friendly matches against Hyundai''s professional teams.

? The number of jobless falls below 1-million for the first time in almost two years... translating to an unemployment rate of 4-point-4 percent.

? And... the ruling and opposition camps seek to regain public trust... by announcing their political resolutions for the coming new millennium.?

? Welcome to Arirang News for Wednesday, December the 22nd.
A sign of warming inter-Korean relations... that''s where we begin this evening''s newscast.?

? Let''s turn now to some stories the local papers are talking about today...

? First off, a North Korean basketball team will be visiting Seoul for the first time.
They''ll be playing against their South Korean counterparts for a series of friendlies starting tomorrow.
The North Korean delegation is led by a vice minister-level official.
Last September, a team from the South visited Pyongyang.

Conglomerates are trying desperately to keep their high-tech personnel from leaving.
This is especially so in the semi-conductor industry... where the brain drain is most evident.
More people are turning to up-and-coming venture companies to make their fortunes.
To prevent them from jumping ship... conglomerates are offering incentives such as stock options... hoping to keep their employees happy.

Finally... the devastating floods in Venezuela.
The death toll from flash floods and mudslides could top 30-thousand.
Most of the victims are buried under huge amounts of mud, rocks and debris which came down as torrential rains pounded Venezula''s Caribbean coast.
Government officials estimate reconstruction could cost billions of dollars.

As for OUR top story this morning... we begin on the economic front... where... ?

? Now to the United States.
The tech-heavy Nasdaq set its 56th record of the year, Tuesday... while the main Dow Jones surged 56 points.
Both markets enjoyed the rallies... after the Federal Reserve decided to keep the current interest rates, before the new year.
Here''s more on the Fed''s decision.

?The decision was announced Tuesday after a closed door meeting of a Federal Reserve group. 
By leaving rates unchanged.... the federal funds rate- the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans- still stands at 5 point 5 percent.
But with projections for continuing strong economic growth... many economist beleive the Federal Reserve will boost rates again in a few months.
However, the Fed''s three rate increases this year haven''t done much to slow the economy which grew by 5 point 5 percent annual rate in the third quarter... far above the three percent which many economist beleive is the most that can be sustained without sparking inflation.
?"There will be no attendant inflation. As it showed itself to this point, there is no reason to think of a slow up next year. Now let the economy and the stock market take care of itself."
The Federal Reserve will reexamine whether to raise interest rates.... next year after financial institutions have dealt with the Year 2-thousand computer date change.?

? millions of dollars of international aid is pouring into Venezuela to help the country recover from its worst natural disaster.
60 tons of food and medicine...
150 thousand plus ppl in need.
temporarily housed in army barracks.
artcl_titl: 베네주엘라 폭우 사망 3-5만명#Rising death toll in Venezuela#
artcl_titl_en: 베네주엘라 폭우 사망 3-5만명#Rising death toll in Venezuela#

artcl_titl: 일 방사능 누출 사고 첫 사망자 발생
artcl_titl_en: 일 방사능 누출 사고 첫 사망자 발생

artcl_ctt:
? For those of you in Korea who''ve waited to see the biggest and brightest full moon in 133 years... we''ll have you know that skies will remain clear throughout the night.
The reason why the moon looks so big tonight... is because today''s the winter solstice... and the fifteenth day of the month according to the lunar calendar.
PLUS... it''s also the time of the year when the moon''s at its closest distance to Earth.
Weather authorities say the moon will be at its fullest... at exactly 2-31 Thursday morning.
Let''s find out then... what tomorrow''s weather will be like in cities around the nation... and elsewhere in the world.
?

? That''s all for this Wednesday.  Thanks for watching.
? Do join us again tomorrow.
Take care and good night.?

? Compared to the start of this century... the world has become a much more democratic place.
That''s according to a report released by the pro-democracy group, Freedom House... which points out, however... South and North Korea are two extremes... when it comes to political rights and civil liberties.
Here''s a closer look.

Seoul is pushing ahead with a plan to dispatch more of its troops to East Timor in compliance with the request by the United Nations. On November 24th UN called for a dispatch of a 717 member infantry battalion to East Timor.?

? The flagship firm of the troubled Daewoo Group.... Daewoo Corporation... faces possible court receivership.
? According to the final audit results announced by creditor banks today... the company''s debt figures have grown worse... since the first and mid-term reviews.
Between the mid-term and FINAL audits... Daewoo Corporation acquired an additional 2-point-8 trillion won in losses... broken down to 2-trillion in bad loans and the rest in reduced assets.
Creditors say... the company''s workout plans need to be revised... including the amount of debt that it''s considered capable of repaying.
It also means creditors will have to take a bigger loss-sharing burden... and if Daewoo''s foreign lenders are unwilling to accept it... court receivership seems to be the only solution.?
artcl_titl: 대우 최종실사내역 악화#Daewoo May Go Under Court Receivership#
artcl_titl_en: 대우 최종실사내역 악화#Daewoo May Go Under Court Receivership#

artcl_ctt:
? According to a survey... more than 60 percent of overseas Koreans appreciate their Korean background.
? More than half of the surveyed meantime, said they''re proud to be Korean... while ten percent answered negatively.
The poll also asked people to list the good characteristics of Koreans... 
And the top three answers were that people on the peninsula are hard-working, compassionate and well-mannered.
On the flip-side though... the respondents frowned upon people''s excessive spending, impatience and lack of team work.
For the poll... one thousand Koreans over the age of twenty living abroad were contacted by the Korea Broadcasting Station and Hanrim (한림) University.?
artcl_titl: 해외동포-민족 정체성 높아#Proud to be Korean#
artcl_titl_en: 해외동포-민족 정체성 높아#Proud to be Korean#

artcl_ctt:
? Hello, this is Newsroom Update.

? North and South Korea are to play in a goodwill game of basketball for two days in Seoul, starting tomorrow.
 The 62-member North Korean delegation .... including  38 male and female players will fly in today from Beijing.
The men''s team will include the world''s tallest known basketball player... Ri Myung-hoon... standing at 2-point-35 meters.
The South Korean teams will be from the Hyundai Group ... which is trying to expand its business in the North.
It''ll be their second faceoff this year... back in September... the two teams played in Pyongyang, the first inter-Korean basketball game in half a century.

? President Kim Dae-jung will meet with Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil today.... just back from his South America trip.
The two are expected to make a final decision on the proposed merger between the ruling coalition partners.... the National Congress for New Politics and the United Liberal Democrats.
Observers believe the President will push for the merger..... he has repeatedly said it is the only way to secure victory in next April''s general elections.
However.... the prime minister had rejected the idea.....saying his party will cooperate with the NCNP....but will remain a separate entity.

? Last week''s devastating mudslides and flash floods in Venezuela may have killed up to 30-thousand people.
Local authorities say with thousands still buried in the mud.... the exact figure may never be known.
Most of the victims were buried under avalanches of mud, rocks and debris that crashed down a mountain range, sweeping away entire towns.
Worst hit was a 100-kilometer stretch of the Caribbean coast in Vargas state, just north of the capital Caracas.
Reconstruction is expected to take several years... and cost billions of dollars.
 
That''s it for now.
Thanks for watching.?

? In local market action...
Overnight gains on Wall Street... along with program buying today... ? brought Korean stock prices back up to the 960 level...
? The benchmark KOSPI rose 9 points... to 967-point-8-3.?
Foreign investors continued to pick up bluechip shares... while individual and institutional players remained in the mood to sell.
Close to 300 million shares changed hands... on market turnover of 4-point-2 trillion won.
Despite the general rise... losers still tripled the number of winners.
? Over on the foreign exchange... the Korean won strengthened again by about 3 won... ending mid-week trading... at 11-31 and-a-half... for every US dollar.?
artcl_titl: Wednesday markets #Wednesday stock and f/x markets#
artcl_titl_en: Wednesday markets #Wednesday stock and f/x markets#

artcl_ctt:
? Among the 48 member countries of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges... the Korean bourse was ranked the eighth strongest performing market this year.
? And among Asian nations... Korea came out on top... with the key KOSPI index soaring 72 percent from the end of last year.
The first and second highest in the world were Turkey and Finland markets... which rocketed 417 and 146 percent respectively.
Only two member countries showed a decline in their stock markets... Belgium with nine percent while Ireland shed two percent.?
artcl_titl: Korea-stocks#Korea stock market ranked eight among FIBV members#
artcl_titl_en: Korea-stocks#Korea stock market ranked eight among FIBV members#

artcl_ctt:
? In Venezuela meantime... reconstruction is underway... to rebuild the nation devastated by last week''s killer rains.
Authorities now estimate up to 30 thousand people may have died... making it Latin America''s worst natural disaster of this century.
Here''s the latest.

? The coastal region just north of Caracas has been devasted.
Venezuela''s Civil Defense reports the natural disaster may have claimed anywhere from 20 to 30 thousand lives.
Most of the victims were buried under avalanches of mud, rocks and debris .
The government reports that 23 thousand homes were destroyed and more than 140 thousand people have been left homeless.
Teams of soldiers, forensic specialists and search dogs descended on the hard hit area of Vargas state to recover bodies.
Authorities say it will be impossible to recover all the bodies... many are believed to have been washed out to sea.
Health officials fear the spread of diarrhea, dehydration, and other health risks due to unsanitary conditions.
More than 68 thousand residents have been evacuated from the disaster zone to nearby Caracas and neighboring cities.
Government officials report reconstruction would cost billions of dollars and take several years... aggravating a deep economic recession.
President Hugo Chavez blames the scale of the accident on previous government administrations... which allowed illegal shantytowns to invade dangerous terrain.?

? Prosecutors are waiting for a court ruling on whether or not a former presidential aide should be arrested... for leaking confidential documents on the so called ''furgate'' scandal.
? Park Ju-sun (박주선) is accused of handing over investigative reports... filed by a police detachment to the presidential office... to former prosecutor-general Kim Tae-jung.
Kim''s wife was implicated in the scandal... in which expensive clothes were allegedly used as bribes.
Park is also charged with holding back witness testimony from the prosecution... information that would have worked against Kim''s wife.
Park insists, though... he''s not guilty of any wrongdoing.?
artcl_titl: 검찰, 박주선 전비서관 사전 영장 청구#Arrest warrant for ex-presidential aide#
artcl_titl_en: 검찰, 박주선 전비서관 사전 영장 청구#Arrest warrant for ex-presidential aide#

? Beware holiday merrymakers... if you''re going to drink... don''t drive.
? That''s the message being enforced by police officers all over the country.
In fact, police carried out an intensive crackdown on drunk drivers last night.
In Seoul, 89-drivers were stopped for being intoxicated behind the wheel.
Of them, 45 had their licenses suspended... while 43 people had their licenses revoked.
One person was arrested for refusing to take the breath-analyzer test.
Police say they''ll set up check points near entertainment districts... from now until January fifth... to check for drunk drivers.?

HOOPS DIPLOMACY CONTINUES

North Korean basketball players arrive in Seoul for friendly matches with and against South Korean teams, continuing a revival in inter-Korean sports exchanges.
-------------------------------
LATEST UNEMPLOYMENT STATS

Korea''s unemployment rate for November, at 4.4%, translates to 970,000 jobless people.  This is the first time in almost two years the figure is below one million.
-------------------------------
TOKYO-PYONGYANG DIALOGUE

In Beijing, North Korean and Japanese negotiators agree to meet again early next year, to ease the way for diplomatic relations.  This week''s meeting was the first in 28 months.
-------------------------------
MILLENNIUM POLITICS

Rival political camps prepare to issue a "New Millennium Political Declaration," putting behind a year of bipartisan bickering and working to regain public trust.

? POSCO Engineering and Construction says it will export 230-million dollars worth of iron-making facilities to Iran... for the first time.
? POSEC sealed the deal yesterday with the National Iranian Steel... to build the plant at the Esfahan Works.
With an annual production capacity of 2-and-a-half million tons... the construction of the facility is expected to take three years.
Officials explain financing arrangements are being made with the Export-Import Bank of Korea.
POSEC plans to provide technical advice to the iron-making plant... and continue to take part in the Iranian govenment''s various steel projects.?
artcl_titl: POSEC to Export $230 Mil. Iron-Making Facility
artcl_titl_en: POSEC to Export $230 Mil. Iron-Making Facility

artcl_ctt:
? As for the open bidding planned for Daewoo Motor... the Samsung Group confirmed... it will not be taking part.
?Samsung... which quit the auto business last fall after Samsung Motors went bankrupt, has long been mentioned as one of the potential bidders.
But following its withdrawal... analysts are now pointing to General Motors, Ford and Hyundai as the most serious contenders.
Korea Develpment Bank said it will receive letters of intent from all interested parties by the end of March ... before picking out one company for exclusive negotiations.
The sale process is slated to be completed by June''s end at the latest.?
artcl_titl: Samsung Vows to Stay Out of Daewoo Motor''s Int''l Bidding
artcl_titl_en: Samsung Vows to Stay Out of Daewoo Motor''s Int''l Bidding

?
?North Korean basketball players arrive in Seoul... for friendly matches... and continue a revival in inter-Korean sports exchanges.

?November''s unemployment rate... at 4.4.%... translates to 970-thousand jobless people... the first time in almost 2 years it''s below a million.

?And in Beijing... North Korean and Japanese negotiators agree to meet again early next year, to ease the way for diplomatic ties.?

?Welcome to Arirang News.
I''m Ahn Junghyun in Seoul.
?And I''m Hyun Chulho.
Stay with us for all the day''s news... on this final edition.?

?In other news... British air carrier... Virgin Atlantic is selling half of its company to Singapore Airlines. 
The going price.. is 960 million dollars.
We have more in this report.

?Richard Branson...the owner of Virgin Atlantic has been moving from one new venture to another...making his airline a big profit maker.
Now his new business move is selling 49 percent stake of the company to Singapore Airline.
The move however will cause a big impact to Virgin Atlantic''s arch rival British Airways...which is now struggling from a low share price of 4-point-5 percent.
?"I think Virgin Atlantic has done very well. I mean for instance, this year we will make bigger profits than British Airways,which I never thought I would be able to say 15 years ago."
Some of the money raised will be poured into Virgin''s new mobile phone business launched several months ago.
The new move to join with another airline has shown that Virgin Atlantic can''t prosper as the soul operator...however the new merge has impressed many who watch the airline industry.
The global partnership among the two carriers will likely occur within the next two months.?

artcl_titl: 김 대통령. DJP, 오늘 합당 문제 조율
artcl_titl_en: 김 대통령. DJP, 오늘 합당 문제 조율

artcl_ctt:
?  The Presidential Commission for the New Millennium held a meeting Tuesday... to start ?the ten-day countdown to the year 2000.
Performers who''ll be part of Korea''s millennial celebrations... on the night of the 31st also attended the gathering.
In a resolution... the members said they would work to make the celebrations a global event.
Today ... the Comission will start receiving New Year wishes from the public.
These written messages will be put into 2000 helium and hot-air balloons... which will be floated from across the country... on the fist morning of the new year.?
artcl_titl: 새천년준비위원회(22BA)#Pres Commish on New Millennium holds rally#
artcl_titl_en: 새천년준비위원회(22BA)#Pres Commish on New Millennium holds rally#

artcl_ctt:
? Leaving behind a year of bipartisan wrangling... the rival political camps have managed to agree on one thing.
That is... to wipe the slate clean ahead of the new millennium... and work together... to regain the trust of the public.
We learn more in this report.

? Politics as usual will not do in the new millennium.
That''s the common recognition between the rival camps... now busy preparing resolutions for the new year.
The ruling camp is reportedly moving to issue a joint ''New Millennium Political Declaration'' with the opposition... aimed at restoring stability and public trust in the political circle.
The National Congress for New Politics has drafted a ten-point declaration which it hopes will be jointly announced following the proposed meeting between President Kim Dae-jung... who heads the party... and Grand National Party leader Lee Hoi-chang.
The joint declaration is expected to contain a pledge by the two leaders to build productive relations and resolve conflicts through dialogue.
It will also call for clean and fair campaigns in the upcoming April general elections... as well as an end to regional antagonism.
But the joint declaration may be difficult to achieve as the two sides are still wide apart on whether to hold parliamentary hearings on the government''s alleged press-taming scheme.
The GNP President is said to be considering issuing a statement of his own after the 27th of this month... urging rival parties to refrain from political mudslinging and partisan bickering.?

artcl_ctt:
? Internet mogul... and founder of Japan''s Softbank Corporation... Masa-yoshi Son... has announced a major project of investing in Korean firms over the next three years.
The details were revealed... as he signed a deal to launch a joint holding company.
Yon Seong-hun reports.

?A hundred million dollars to be invested in Korean venture and Internet-related firms over the next three years.
That''s the gist of a plan... announced in Seoul Tuesday... by Masayoshi Son... founder and president of Softbank.
The vehicle for those investments will be a joint holding company... to be launched next month... between Softbank and Naray Corporation.

??"I think in the next century, Korea will play a very important role in the global market for the Internet society to come."

Softbank will hold an 80 percent stake... and Naray... a local mobile ?communications services provider... will have the rest.
Son says total investments could also rise to as high as 300 million dollars in that time.
?The Korean-based firm... called Softbank Holdings Korea... will be among the 12 that run some 140 companies worldwide.
It''s an empire that includes major stakes in big Internet names like Yahoo!, Yahoo! Japan, E-Trade and Geocities.
Softbank also recently set up Internet-based stock trading platforms... called Nasdaq Japan and Europe... to be integrated with the U-S Nasdaq.

?"We are willing to provide our capability to connect with Nasdaq U-S, Nasdaq Europe, Nasdaq Japan, and possibliiy some kind of partnership with the Korean stock market... [it] . might be a possiblity."

A second-generation Korean-Japanese... with a vision for the Internet and the homeland.
Yon Seong-hun, Arirang T-V.?

artcl_titl_en: Korea-investment#Softbank to invest $100 mln in Korea#

Take care and good night.?

? U-S embassies worldwide won''t be issuing visas... at the start of the new year.
? The State Department says there will be a two-day suspension for NON-immigrant visa services... and two-WEEKS for immigrant visas.
Washington''s citing Y2K worries for the move.
Some officials add... there''s also the possible threat of terrorism... targetting Americans during millennial celebrations.
Visa operations at the US Embassy in Cambodia... were suspended temporarily Monday... for security reasons.
And last week... Washington decided to indefinitely close its missions in Ecuador... in response to terrorist threats.?

? After a mixed session... Korean stock prices finished this Tuesday moderately lower.
? The main index DID rise to almost 990 at one point... on continued strong performances by telecom stocks...
? But profit-taking brought the KOSPI down 8 and-a-quarter points in the end... to 958-point-8.?
Trading was active with 282 million shares being exchanged... on turnover of nearly 4 trillion won.
Losers swamped gainers by a 7 to 1 margin...
Market leader SK Telecom soared to a new high, though... hitting 3-point-7 million won per share.
? On the forex market, meanwhile... the Korean currency strengthened slightly against the U-S dollar... closing up less than a won... at 11-34-point-2.?

? First off, the government will tighten restriction qualification for companies that want to register on the KOSDAQ market.
And one of the first measures taken... 58-firms will be ousted from the secondary stock market... for poor performance... by the first half of next year.

And more on venture businesses...
Korea University professors have come together to form a company that produces translation software.
The venture firm focuses on getting high-quality translations from English to Korean.
The research team hopes to finish the project next year... and by the year 2001... get the product out on the market.
As for long-term plans... the venture company hopes to expand to translate Korean to Russian, Chinese and other languages.

And on the subject of schools... female cadets have made a big impression on both the army and naval academies.
The two military academies have announced that female cadets topped the admission tests.
It''s only been a few years since the military schools have been accepting female students.
18-year old Song Sang-hee(송상희) scored the highest at the naval academy... while at the army academy... the top honors went to Lee Jun-shil(이준실)... who just narrowly beat her brother.

And our top story this morning comes from Russia...
where...?

? Russia''s centrist parties are emerging as the winners from Sunday''s general elections... for the first time in the post-Soviet era.
In fact... the biggest winner of all... many say... is Prime Minister Vladimir Putin... who could well be on his way to succeeding President Boris Yeltsin.
Here''s more.

? Russia''s general election is being hailed by many as a peaceful revolution which has diminished the dominance of the communist party.
The newly created Unity Party, which is backed by the Kremlin and supports Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, led the four centrist parties winning more than 25 percent of the votes so far.
The results give Putin a major boost in the Presidential election next year, as he seeks to succeed Boris Yeltsin.
Despite losing ground in the Duma, Communist leader Gennady Zyuganov said he was pleased with his party''s performance.
? "Our party, the Communist party, has played and will continue to play a key role in the political life of the country.
Our party has already taken first place on the federal level and with individual candidates."
Half the 450 Duma seats go to constituencies, the other 225 are allocated to parties that win more than five percent.
The Fatherland-All Russia coalition, led by Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov and former Premier Yevgeny Primakov, managed to recieve 12 percent of the vote.
Primakov recently announced he will run for President next year.
Projections by the Central Election Commission showed that the centrists will have more than 180 seats in the Duma, while the Communists were expected to fill 111 seats.?

? Four firms have inked a deal to set up a combined corporation... that''ll run the merged petrochemical units of Hyundai and Samsung.
? The Federation of Korean Industries... which initiated the deal... said it received signatures from Hyundai and Samsung, as well as two Japanese investors... Japan Bank for International Cooperation  and Mitsui.
According to the pact, the two Japanese firms will invest about 430 million dollars in the combined firm... for a 25-percent stake.
They''ll also provide 1-and-a-half billion dollars in loans... at an annual interest rate of 2-percent repayable over 10 years.
Some issues remain unresolved, though... like who will have export rights... but with the basic agreement signed... the combined company is expected to be launched by the end of February.?
artcl_titl: Basic Pact Signed on Setup of Unified Petrochemicals Firm
artcl_titl_en: Basic Pact Signed on Setup of Unified Petrochemicals Firm

? With the fast spread of information technology in everyday life, the number of Personal Computer users in this country has now topped 12 million.
? According to statistics released by the National Computerization Agency... Internet users are numbered at 5-point-7 million... while the figure for P-C online communication users... has broken through the 6-million mark.
Of the total national population... over 38-percent of those aged between 13 and 59... are now using P-Cs...  while 18-percent are surfing the net.
However... E-commerce remains sluggish... with only 1-percent using the service.?

? ...the centrist parties are enjoying their biggest support... in the post-Soviet Union era.
80 percent of Sunday''s ballots have been counted... ? and the Unity party, endorsed by Russian Prime  Minister Vladimir Putin... grabbed 24 percent... which is less than one percentage point... behind the Communist Party.
Centrist parties did well overall... and analysts say will likely claim more than half the seats in the legislature.
That could mean an end to the bitter fueding between President Boris Yeltsin and the old Communist-dominated Duma... paving the way to greater economic reforms.?

This means... detectives will be required to give their name cards to victims or their families... and accompany police officers when visiting crime scenes.
Also... they have to let the victims know within ten days... how the investigation''s going.
Authorities say the change is intended to minimize the number of visits by victims to the police station... in order to give testimony.?

? Koreans are eating less rice.
According to the Rural Development Administration... ? per-capita annual rice consumption... has gone down by 37 kilograms over the past three decades.
Each Korean, on average... ate 136 and a half kilograms of rice... back in 19-70...
The figure has been declining steadily since then... falling below 100 for the first time last year... to 99 kilograms.?

? Talks between Japan and North Korea have hit a snag in Beijing.
? The two sides were scheduled to open negotiations on establishing diplomatic relations YESTERDAY... but the talks were delayed after Red Cross delegates from both countries got caught in a stalemate.
Japanese and North Korean Red Cross officials were unable to see eye to eye on a critical issue... concerning missing Japanese nationals... alleged to have been abducted by North Korean agents.
Tokyo wants the North to clear up the kidnapping allegations... while Pyongyang maintains it knows nothing about the missing people.
The government-to-government meeting is expected to be held today... following the Red Cross talks.?

? Another 20 millimeters of snow is expected on Korea''s southern most island of Cheju... ? where a heavy snow warning remains in effect for the third day.
As much as 70 millimeters of snow is reported from Mount Halla''s peak... Cheju''s highest point.
Travels to and from the island are suffering as a result...
Authorities have blocked off some roads... while Yosu and Mokpo airports remain closed.
Strong winds this morning pushed temperatures even lower around the island... dropping to a low of minus six degrees Celsius.
Many schools on Cheju Island remain closed for the second day.?

? President Kim Dae-jung is meeting the heads of the top 30 business groups... for a luncheon at Chongwade today.
? But... eight groups that are under court  receivership or a workout program... have been excluded from the gathering.
Corporate restructuring is expected to be one of the topics of discussion.
Also on the agenda... ways to promote investment in local businesses... and to improve labor-management relations.
The business leaders are expected to call for the easing of regulations on setting up holding companies... and greater access to social overhead projects.?

?? Seoul''s Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry says... this is because Washington recently ruled that the dumping margin of Korea''s number one chipmaker... was over 10 percent between 19-97 and 98... the highest level ever.
The Ministry adds... Hyundai has ONE month to file a petition with the U-S... or pay duties of 10-point-4-4 percent.
Hyundai is protesting the ruling, though... saying it will take the case to the Court of International Trade.?

? Foreign advertising companies are increasing their presence in Korea.
By the year''s end... they''re expected to grab a ten percent share of the domestic market.
Here''s more.

? Through either direct management or joint ventures... foreign advertisers are expected to make up ten percent of the local industry by the end of this year.
Hyundai''s subsidiary... Kumkang (금강) or Diamond Ad today turned over 80 percent of its shares to U-K''s Cordiant Communications... for 120 million dollars.
In another development, Cheil Communications... another leading advertizer... agreed last week to set up a joint firm with Japan''s Hakuh-odo (하쿠오도).
To be called Hakuh-odo-Cheil... the Japanese partner will hold 51 percent of the business.
There were other deals earlier this year as well.
First, the SK Group sold off its affiliate Taekwang Multi-Ad... to a multinational firm TBWA.
Also... France''s Publicis took on 60 percent of Well Communications.
Industry watchers explain... local advertizers have been shopping for foreign investments since the economic downturn two years ago.
Based on advertising expenses... Korea''s ad market is estimated at five trillion won... or 4-point-4 billion dollars.?

? Welcome to Biz Today for this Tuesday, December 21st.  ?

? Korean-Japanese business tycoon Masa-yashi Son is currently in Seoul.
And as we see now... his trip could mark the start of big changes... in the local tech industry.

? Masayashi Son flew into Seoul yesterday... with plans to invest in local Internet ventures.
A flock of reporters were on hand to speak to the business tycoon upon his arrival.
He said he plans to invest in Internet companies... but refused to mention specific figures, saying it''s too early to say.
However, there are reports that Son will invest hundreds of billions of won... over the next three years.
Among the first items on his itinerary is today''s meeting with officials of Narae Telecom.
The two sides plan to set up a joint holding company.
Son is the founder and C-E-O of Softbank.
Thanks to the internet boom, the company recently became Japan''s number five company... in terms of market capitalization.
In a recent interview with Time magazine... Son revealed his goal... of expanding his business empire to 780 companies worldwide... within the next five years.
Local sources predict that Son''s investment here will be sizeable...
They say that could lead to a new face for the local Internet industry.?

? Next week... the ruling National Congress for New Politics will begin organizing electoral district chapters... for its soon-to-be-launched "Millennium New Democratic Party".
Ruling lawmakers also plan to tour the nation... to garner public support for the new party.
The junior coalition partner... the United Liberal Democrats... meanwhile... reconfirmed it will NOT merge with the N-C-N-P...
Instead... to elevate its party prestige... the U-L-D plans to attract more conservatives.
The opposition Grand National Party will also recruit new faces in time for the April election.?

? The head of Korea''s financial watchdog agency says... all but one of the top five conglomerates... by the end of the month... should be able to lower their debt-to-equity ratios to under 200 percent.
Here''s a closer look at the reforms in the corporate sector.

? Korea''s top companies... except Daewoo... are expected to reduce their debt-to-equity ratios to below 200-percent by year''s end.
That''s according to Financial Supervisory Commissioner Lee Hun-jae... during a Chongwadae meeting on the progress of corporate and financial reforms.
Among big business groups... Hyundai, Samsung, LG and SK  have pledged to trim their debt ratios. 
The financial watchdog says... the average debt-to-equity ratio among affiliates of the top four fell to 255-percent in June from over 350-percent at the end of last year.
Already, twelve firms including affiliates of Lotte, Samyang, and Dacom have lowered their debt ratios to under 200 percent.
Concerning Daewoo Group affiliates, the government plans to sign a management improvement pact in the next few weeks. 
However... if negotiations with foreign creditors fail, the F-S-C commissioner says Daewoo Corporation will be put under court receivership.
Meanwhile... Lee said restructuring is complete in all but one of the seven targetted industries...
A blueprint for the petrochemical industry... will be drawn up within the year.?

? The founder and CEO of Japan''s Softbank.... , is said to be planning on investing in local internet ventures.
Masayashi Son, arriving in Seoul last night.. refused to mention specific figures, saying it''s too early to say.
However,  there are reports that Son will invest hundreds of billions of won... over the next three years.
As the first step... Son plans to meet with officials of Narae Telecom this morning... to seal plans for a joint holding company in Korea.
He recently revealed his goal... to expand his business empire to 780 companies worldwide within the next five years.

? For the first time since the Soviet collapse in 19-91, a majority of Russian voters have opted for moderate, centrist parties.
The strong performance of Unity, the main centrist party in Sunday''s election... is a strong endorsement for Prime Minister Vladimir Putin and his tough handling of the conflict in Chechnya.
Centrist groups appear set to take more than half the seats in the State Duma, the lower chamber of parliament.
It is a far cry from the previous two elections when Communists and right-wing nationalists triumphed.
Communists have blocked many of President Boris Yeltsin''s efforts at economic reforms.

? And, the final preparations are being made for this afternoon''s launch of a Korean satellite...dubbed Arirang One or KOMPSAT.
At about 4:12 this afternoon local time, the high-tech craft will blast off from Vandenberg Air Force in California.
KOMPSAT, which stands for Korean Multipurpose Satellite... is the centerpiece project of Korea''s space program.
At an altitude of 685 kilometers, the satellite will orbit the earth up to 15 times a day... mapping Korean territory, monitoring ocean color, movements and other earth resources.

That''s it for now.
Thanks for watching.?

? The Cabinet passed 34 laws this morning... including those on various taxes.
? Taking a look at some of the changes...
Starting next year... the tax rate on the traditional Korean liquor soju... will more than DOUBLE... to 72 percent.
The tax on imported whiskey, on the other hand... will go down from 100... to 72 percent.
The rate for beer is also set to be lowered by 15 percentage points to... 115 percent.
And in the year 2001... the global income tax will be revived.
Meanwhile... tax rates on incomes from interest and dividends... will be brought down in stages... from the current 22 percent... to 20 percent next year, and 15 percent the year after.?

artcl_titl_en: 각의, 34개 법률 공포안 # Cabinet Passes 34 Laws #

artcl_ctt:
? We go now to California''s Vandenburg Air Force Base... in the U-S... where final preparations are underway to put Korea''s seventh satellite in space.
Scheduled to take off in four hours time... the high-tech craft... dubbed Arirang One or KOMPSAT... is Korea''s first ever multi-purpose satellite.
Here''s a closer look.

? Korea''s KOMPSAT will soar into space aboard a Taurus rocket today at 4-12 Korea Standard Time.
KOMPSAT, which stands for Korean Multipurpose Satellite... is the centerpiece project of Korea''s space program.
The 47-kilogram satellite will orbit the earth 14-to-15 times a day for three years at an altitude of 685-kilometers.
Its main mission... utilizing high-tech equipment to map Korean territory, monitor ocean color, movements and other earth resources... as well as perform various physics experiments in space.
KOMPSAT, or Arirang One, is the first satellite that was made with the participation of Korean scientists... from its inception to testing and to the final production.
It was jointly built by Korean and U-S researchers at a cost of 112-billion dollars.
A proto flight model of the satellite was made by a California-based company, T-R-W... while the actual flight body was assembled and tested by engineers at the Korea Aerospace Research Institute.
In all... 80-percent of the satellite''s parts were manufactured by seven domestic companies.
If all goes according to plan... the satellite will lift off this afternoon... 13-minutes after the launch... it will separate from the rocket.
The first signals should be received approximately 15-minutes later.
Korea plans to launch another multi-purpose science satellite... built entirely with Korean technology, in 2003.?

Chongwadae says the gathering was President Kim''s idea... as he wants to hear the others'' opinions on next year''s state agenda.
The chief executive is also slated to hold separate talks with the Prime Minister on the following day... to discuss the proposed merger between the two ruling coalition parties.?

Telecom and technology shares were down... with NTT off 2-point-4 percent.
Manufacturers, export-related stocks, auto-industry issues were mixed.... and banks were the only sector to clearly move ahead.?

? The judicial reform committee has finalized a bill on reforming the nation''s legal system.
? Under the proposal... the term of physical detention by police... will be shortened from the current ten to five days.
And prosecutors will be given the power to grant bail... as judges do... provided they secure monetary... or other means to prevent flight.
Other measures include... simplifying physical detention and criminal investigation procedures... and removing the ceiling on the number of people allowed to take the bar exam.?

? The Korean government has released a set of policy guidelines for the year 2000.
? Under the theme "New Millennium, New Hope"... Seoul''s policies next year... will focus on five key areas.
National unity was given top priority... followed by completion of administrative reforms... realization of a knowledge-based society... economic advancement... and promotion of inter-Korean cooperation.
The government says it will instruct all of its offices to follow these guidelines... in drawing up policies for the new year.?

A handful of heavyweight stocks pulled the Hang Seng up, as technology shares continue to attract the most attention.
The index gained one fifth of a percent to close at 16-thousand-248... amid thinning turnover, ahead of the Christmas holiday.

Down under, the All Ordinaries shed almost one percent in light trading... to close at 31-07.
Investors there are said to be nervously eyeing the results of the US Fed meeting.
While the U.S. is not expected to hike rates, many analysts feel it may shift to a tightening bias... that would signal possible rate increases in the future.

Next, the day''s exchange rates.?

INTERNET BUSINESS IDEAS

Masayoshi Son, Internet mogul and founder of Japan''s Softbank Corporation, says he will invest in as many as 100 Korean firms in the next three years.
-------------------------------

The head of Korea''s financial watchdog agency says all the top five conglomerates, except Daewoo, should be able to lower their debt-to-equity ratios to below 200% by year''s end.
-------------------------------
DESTINATION OUTER SPACE

The Korean Multipurpose Satellite (KOMPSAT), centerpiece of Seoul''s space program, is launched successfully into orbit from the U.S. state of California at 4:12 PM Korea Time.

North Korean and Japanese Red Cross negotiators, in Beijing, China, agree to resume, from next spring, visits to Japan by Japanese women living in the North.

? ( S-O-T .... 3 seconds )
At around 9:28 A-M on June 15th, a North Korean ship first opened fire on South Korean navy patrol.
But the military exchange came after 14 minutes of intense shoving between inter-Korean ships on the West Sea near Yonpyong Island. 
?( " We were ordered by the superior command to defend the NLL at all costs and not to make a preemptive attack.
Under these instructions, our cruisers were compelled to suffer the collisions initiated by North Korean patrol ships.
It was as if we were boxing with our hands and feet tied together.")
After the go ahead to respond to North Korean fire, the clash ended in an overwhelming victory for the South.
One North Korean boat... believed to be a torpedo ship... was hit and went under.
One patrol vessel nearly sank... and several others were damaged.
South Korean ships suffered only minor damages.
?(" I think this was a victory achieved through our solid national security policy.
I am certain that North Korea will engage in future provocation to avenge its defeat in the West Sea.
That is why the Republic of Korea Navy is making every effort to keep up a foolproof security posture.")
The incident made a statement to the world that South Korea is determined to maintain security and protect its sovereignty.
Seoul''s Defense Ministry says the developments following the clash proved North Korea had tried to use the border incident as a negotiating card in missile talks and food assistance.
Eventually, North Korea, for its needs, pledged to forego missile tests and improved ties with Japan.
? In numerous cases, Washington had praised Seoul''s handling of the West Sea provocation through which South Korea demonstrated its superior arms capability.
The whole incident served as a reminder that the policy of embracing North Korea cannot be achieved without a strong defense posture.
This is Park Jonghong Arirang TV.?

On the recent labor unrest... the President said the government would stick to three principles.
Top priority to corporate competitiveness.
Legal and peaceful means of resolving conflicts.
And thirdly... implementing policies that work for both labor and management.?

? North Korean and Japanese Red Cross officials managed to agree on some issues... that open the way for their governments to start talking about normalizing estranged ties.
First... the Red Cross negotiators agreed to resume next spring... visits to Japan by Japanese wives in the North.
And second... to have Pyongyang investigate the alleged kidnappings of Japanese citizens by its agents.
The Japanese Red Cross also said it would ask its government to resume food aid... to help ease the North''s chronic shortage.
These shipments were suspended last year... after North Korea test-fired a missile over Japan.
Japan''s chief negotiatior says the aid could begin as soon as this coming March.?

Children were invited to the White House in an annual gathering for a Christmas story reading.
This year, the President read a 19th century poem by Clement Moore entitled "''Twas the Night Before Christmas".
The youngsters joined in by filling in the key phrases.
The reading was followed by a choir performance of the carol "Rudolph the Red-nosed Reindeer."
The week before Christmas is traditionally the time when the President and First Lady welcome children into the White House.?

?Two major rail carriers are joining forces to create the largest railroad in North America.  The teaming of Canadian National and Burlington Northern rail ways...is an effort to win back some of the market that''s been dominated by the trucking industry.
Here''s more.
?The heads of the  two largest rail freight carriers in North America were in Montreal on Monday to sign the deal which would make them ... the largest line in the continent... out ranking Union Pacific.
Canadian National and Burlington Northern railways will know be called....North American Railways.
It''s trains will move across the continent form Los Angeles to Halifax, Nova Scotia, and from the Gulf of Mexico to Vancouver British Columbia.
The merger has been prompted by the truck industry.
?"This is the perfect time for us to get together because now we''ll have a 50-thousand mile network providing rail service that is truck-competative across North America. That''s what we are going to do. We are going to concentrate on getting this transaction consummated in the next 18 months."
Rail carriers have been spending millions to upgrade tracks and trains to compete with the dominate trucking industry.
Canadian Northern has been criticized for selling out to a U-S counter part ... but officials brushed it aside saying the merger was a way to stay competitive.
The new company will be based in Montreal... and generate 12 point 5 billion dollars in revenue.?

? A local venture company says it''s developed the world''s first cellular phone that identifies the user through his or her finger print.
? The developer... Pass 21st Century... claims the technology is competely error-free... and would make it impossible for others to fake the user''s identity.
The phone can be used to replace a wide range of functions that require personal identification... such as transactions using credit cards or electronic cash.
It could even do away with dependence on keys.
The company says Samsung Electronics has agreed to begin mass-producing the wonder phone... starting next June.?

? Venezuelan authorities now say... the death toll from last week''s massive mudslides and floods will be at least 10-thousand.
? In fact... according to the Foreign Minister... the number of casualties could even hit 25-thousand...  given the extent of the damage... from the country''s worst natural disaster ever.
Authorities have so far recovered 15-hundred bodies... as they continue to search for survivors.
About 200-thousand people are reported to be homeless.
Officials say reconstruction would cost billions of dollars and take several years.?

? The central bank says... foreign-invested companies enjoyed better business in the first half of this year... seeing their profits more than double what their domestic counterparts made.
Our next report... looks at why.

? Foreign-invested Korean firms were more profitable and financially healthier than locally-invested companies in the first six months of this year.
The Bank of Korea says companies with foreign investment exceeding 50 percent... posted a profit ratio of six-and-a-half percent against sales during this period... an almost three percent rise from a year ago.
The ratio for Korean companies was just four percent.
Simply put, this means foreign-invested companies earned 65 won for every one-thousand won they sold... which is 25 won more than Korean companies.
Central bank officials say this is due mainly to foreign exchange gains from the won''s appreciation and reductions in the cost of borrowing.
In addition, foreign-invested firms reduced their debt ratios from an average of more than 190 percent at the end of last year to about 150 percent in June this year.
The average debt ratio for Korean companies in June was 260 percent.
The BOK also found that the higher the percentage of foreign investment... the better the bottom line.
Companies with one-hundred percent foreign investment managed to post a profit ratio of seven percent and a debt ratio of a little over 110 percent.?

? Also this year...
Efforts to launch a new round of global trade talks... came to a premature end.
? Representatives from 135 WTO member nations gathered in the U-S city of Seattle late November... to finalize trade liberalization deals for the agriculture and services industries... areas that had been left over from the 19-92 Uruguay Round.
But... the ministerial meeting collapsed... amid violent anti-WTO demonstrations... complaints by developing countries that they were being left out of main discussions... and discord over several key issues, particularly agriculture.
For now... WTO members agree they need a cooling-off period before starting a fresh round of talks... most likely due early next year.?

? That is our report on this Tuesday morning December twenty-first.
Thank you for watching and please join us back here same time tomorrow!?

the scheduled launch of Korea''s first multi-purpose satellite... KOMPSAT.?

Those are the stories at this hour.

? Now to the successful launch of Korea''s KOMPSAT... or Arirang One satellite.
? 13 minutes after taking off from California''s Vandenburg Air Force Base... the satellite separated itself from the Taurus rocket... and reached its designated orbit... at an altitude of 685 kilometers.
KOMPSAT, which stands for Korean Multipurpose Satellite... is the centerpiece project of Seoul''s space program.
Weighing 47-kilograms... the satellite will orbit the earth 14-to-15 times a day for three years.
Its main mission is to create an electronic map of the country... monitor ocean colors, movements and other earth resources... as well as conduct various physics experiments in space.
Arirang One is the first satellite with Korean participation... from its inception... to testing... and to the final production.
It was jointly built by Korean and U-S researchers at a cost of 200 million dollars.?

?Macau is now a Special Administrative Region... being governed under the one country two systems formula... like Hong Kong.
At midnight last Sunday... China took back the enclave... ending the four and a half centuries of Portugese rule.
The Chinese were in celebration as fireworks lit up the skies of Beijing on Sunday.
Last week, President Kim Dae-jung held talks with visiting Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan at Chongwadae.
Stressing the need for enhancing bilateral ties, Kim said, since diplomatic relations were set up in 19-92... China has become Korea''s second-largest investment market and third-largest trading partner.
The President said he''s looking forward to more positive exchanges with China in the 21st century.
Of all the items on President Kim''s agenda on the third ASEAN plus three summit in Manila... one particular event stands out as the biggest achievement of this outing.
The first ever gathering among the leaders of the three Northeast Asian nations... namely Korea, China and Japan.
Chinese Premier Zhu Rong-ji and Japanese Prime Minister Obuchi accepted President Kim''s proposal that they launch a joint study on ways to promote economic cooperation.
Meanwhile... China''s entry into the World Trade Organization is not likely to increase Korea''s exports at least for the time being.
Hyundai Economic Research Institute says... Korea''s trade with China will pick up after the year 2005.
That''s when China is expected to slash its tariffs on foreign cars from the current rate of 80 to 100 percent down to 25 percent.
The local think tank also adds the deal was hammered out by the United States... mainly opening up the service sector... from telecommunications to finance.
So the agreement is not necessarily going to mean huge benefits to tech-oriented trading partners in Korea.

Money that allegedly went to fund Lee Hoi-chang... then the ruling party candidate.
Lee Suk-hee has been avoiding returning to Korea from the U-S... and will likely be extradited... with the Seoul-Washington criminal extradition treaty taking effect yesterday.
His arrest warrant is valid until June 20th next year.
Prosecutors are also preparing to extradite Lee Suk-chae, former Communication Minister who is charged with accepting bribes in exchange for business favors.?

?He''s changed the way millions do their shopping... and for that Time Magazine has name him person of the year.
Jeff Bezos... dubbed the king of cybercommerce... now has another credit to his name.
?He''s the man behind the hugely successful website amazon dot com... putting Jeff Bezos on the front cover as Time''s Person of the year. 
?"I am the most suprised person on the planet as to what''s happened to Amazon dot com. We hoped to build a successful company. You have to be optimistic to leave a job and do a start up company but nobody could have predicted what happened."
In 1994, Bezos quit his job at a New York investment firm to found the Seattle based internet company.
Its website quickly became the Goliath of Internet bookselling and soon branched out into music and video.
Now Amazon is trying to build itself into an on-line superstore... selling everthing from software ato toys and home improvement items.
?"Jeff Bezos, we''ll remember years from now as being the symbol of internet commerce. This is the year in which all of a sudden everybody you know is shopping on the web."
Bezos admits the earliest his company will likely turn a profit is in the year 2-thousand 3.
Profit or no profit... shopping will never be the same.?

? In Venezuela... the death toll is now estimated to be in the thousands... following last week''s merciless downpours.
While the rain let up somewhat over the weekend... tens of thousands are still reportedly trapped in Vargas, just north of the capital Caracas.
Let''s now take a closer look at the devastation in Venezuela.

? Thousand have been stranded on a desolate stretch of the Carribean coast in Venezuela....
And its taking a battle plan to get them out.
A warship and dozens of army helicopters evacuated many of the desperate flood vicitms.
Navy ships continue to move up and down the coast looking for survivors.
Children waiting to be rescued played with the friends.... while their parent were undertandably impatient to get to safety.
Military helicopters took the wounded out first.
In Caraballeda... makeshift camps are housing hundreds.
On site... the basics are available but doctors say conditions are dire.
?"We''ve found an enormous number of ?people in critical condition. The worse though is that there''s a huge number of decomposing corpses." 
A large epidemic is predicted to spread within a day. 
Of those who escaped the flood... how many will be able to run away from disease and infection is unknown.?

Seoul is right now posting a chilly... minus eleven degrees Celsius.
A heavy snow warning is still issued in the southern regions of Cholla and North Choongchong provinces.?

Authorities caught him Friday, with materials... capable of producing a large explosive device.
The materials are reportedly similar to those used to bomb New York''s World Trade Center, six years ago.
The Algerian-born reportedly had a motel reservation in Seattle near the Space Needle tourist attraction... where thousands of revelers are expected to gather on New Year''s Eve.?

? The Communist Party in Russia... has made a strong showing in Sunday''s parliamentary elections.
? Votes counted so far show... the pro-Kremlin party Unity... running closely behind in second place... while liberals are doing better than anticipated.
The general elections are the third since the breakup of the communist Soviet Union... with 450 seats in the lower house of Duma up for grabs.
According to exit polls, the Communist Party secured 28-percent of the vote... and the Unity bloc got 24-percent.
The Unity party also known as "The Bear" was founded two months ago... to support Kremlin policies as well as Prime Minister Vladimir Putin... who is hoping to succeed President Boris Yeltsin, next year.?

? Most major markets in the region... made a positive start to the trading week... reacting to the firm advance on Wall Street Friday... and shrugging off fears of a U-S interest rate hike.

In Tokyo... the Nikkei 225 snapped a five-session run of declines... closing up 80 points at 18-thousand 175.
Traders said, though... the gains were largely limited to Sony and Toyota... which investors have begun to treat as information technology-related issues.?

? Despite the overall economic recovery... Korean construction firms saw reduced earnings this year.
The average contract amount dropped to under ten billion won per builder... for the first time in a decade.
We learn why... in this report.

? It''s because... the construction sector is getting more crowded.
19-99 alone saw the number of construction firms jump 26 percent... to 5-thousand 300.
So with more companies in the business... earnings at individual firms are dropping.
Industry sources report this year... the yearly project amount per builder dropped to its lowest in a decade... to 8-point-9 billion won.
New projects signed this year total 10-point-75 trillion won... which industry experts say is NOT enough to keep many large builders in business.
The decline began a decade ago in 19-89... when the Korean government moved to liberalize the licensing of construction firms... hoping to boost the industry.
In 19-93... project figures averaged 26 billion won... then 19 billion three years later.
Then last year, when the economy bottomed out... the total plunged to 11 billion won.
The number of companies in the construction business... posted 2-thousand 650, ten years ago... broke 4-thousand last year and then the five thousand this year.?
artcl_titl: 건설업체 평균 수주액 하락#Construction-average cost down#
artcl_titl_en: 건설업체 평균 수주액 하락#Construction-average cost down#

artcl_ctt:
?The Hyosung Group has sold its shares in Korea Engineering Plastic for 100-million dollars... to a multinational firm based in the U-S.
?Hyosung says the deal brings down the group''s debt to equity ratio to 160 percent... and marks the end of its reform program.
Korea Engineering Plastic is a joint venture... set up by Hyosung and Japan''s Mitsubishi... 12 years ago.
Its profits this year are expected to reach 110-million won.
And Hyosung''s getting more than a 20-fold profit by selling its stake in the plastics firm.
Company officials say some of the money will go to strengthening core businesses.
As part of the deal... the new owner has agreed to keep all current employees.?
artcl_titl: 효성- ''한국엔지니어링'' 1억 달러에 매각#Hyosung sells stake in KEP#
artcl_titl_en: 효성- ''한국엔지니어링'' 1억 달러에 매각#Hyosung sells stake in KEP#

artcl_ctt:
? Korea is estimated to have doled out more than 20 billion dollars in royalties for foreign technology... over the past three decades.
? The Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry says royalty payments between 19-62 and the first half of this year... reached over 19 billion dollars.
Another billion dollars is thought to have been paid during the latter half of the year... bringing the total to over 20 billion.
More than half of that amount has been paid to the U-S, followed by Japan and Germany.
Royalty payments for technology transfers remained under 200 million dollars per year in the 19-80''s... but since 19-96, the amount has surged ten-fold to over two billion dollars.?

? Civil servants in Korea have more reasons to cheer the coming new year... 
Their paychecks could get almost ten-percent fatter.
And as we see in our next story... raising the wages in the public sector... is all about keeping the balance.

? The government is seeking to put the bill into effect starting January 1st... with approval from the cabinet and the president later this month.
At the very least... the revision calls for a 3-percent rise in the base salary for civil servants.
The bill also provides a leeway for nearly 7-percent wage hike in terms of benefits.
And to bring up the level of pay closer to that of the private sector... another 3-percent rise will be allowed.
All this would bring the permissible range of wage hikes to 9-point-7 percent.
A look at how this will affect top level government officials... President Kim Dae-jung will get 104 million won in annual salary following the change... or about 87-thousand dollars. 
The Prime Minister will receive 80 million won and other members of the cabinet... some 57 million.
The government says it plans to improve income levels in the public sector ... currently at an average 87 percent of the private corporations ... closer to 98 percent by the year 2003.
And to attract various experts to the government-led sector ... the bill will scrap a ceiling on wages to special recruits.?
artcl_titl: Public Workers Pay Increase#Public Servants Pay to Go Up#
artcl_titl_en: Public Workers Pay Increase#Public Servants Pay to Go Up#

? So glad you can join us.
Welcome to Arirang News for Tuesday, December 5th.
I''m Cho Heemyung... with a look at stories making news in Korea.?

? Up next... going after outlaws.
An extradition treaty between Korea and the United States is now in effect.
And Seoul has reportedly started to collect names of Koreans... some of them HIGH-PROFILE names... whose days of hiding out are numbered.

?Korea''s Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister, Hong Soon-young and U-S Ambassador to Korea, Stephen Bosworth have exchanged letters of ratification for the new treaty.
This means from now on... Korean criminal suspects in the U-S... who face a prison term of one-year or longer will be extradited.   
Seoul''s Justice Ministry says... it is already in the process of selecting the first 20 people out of an estimated 286 local fugitives.
Among the high-profile names... former official of the then National Tax Administration... Lee Suk-hee.
Lee is suspected of illegally raising campaign funds for the Grand National Party during the 19-97 presidential election.
Former Information-Communication Minister, Lee Suk-chae is reportedly on the list as well.
He is being charged with interfering in the licensing process of Personal Communications Service providers.
The Justice Ministry says... those who are suspected of committing economic crimes will be among the first to be brought back to Korea.?

? Leading musicians from the two Koreas shared a stage in Pyongyang... last night.
? The special event was co-organized by a South Korean television station and the North''s Korean Asia-Pacific Peace Committee.
Musicians from the South went to the communist North via Beijing... as there are no direct plane routes or phone lines linking the two sides, since the Korean War fifty years ago.
Featured in the lineup... the group, Koreana... which sang at the 88 Seoul Olympics.
To wrap up the historic night... performers from both sides of the border sang together hand-in-hand... along with the audience.?

?
?It''s been a little over a year since the first cruise ship set sail to Mount Kumgang in North Korea.



The Mount Kumgang Tour project... inter-Korean exchange. 

Include Mt Kumgang--economic cooperation, Perry''s package deal, Berline missile talks, basketball-- inter Korean exchange.

? President Kim says... some clauses in the controversial National Security Law need to be revised.
? One of them is a portion that defines North Korea as "an anti-state entity."
Under that description... he said... there should be no Mount Kumgang cruise tour... or inter-Korean dialogue.
The President was speaking to a group of Christian leaders yesterday at Chongwadae.
Two other clauses Kim pointed out... one that penalizes someone who intentionally fails to notifiy authorities of a Pyongyang sympathizer.
And the other... outlawing encouragement or praise of the communist North.?
artcl_titl: DJ 보안법(22KBR)#Pres Kim urges change to Security Law#
artcl_titl_en: DJ 보안법(22KBR)#Pres Kim urges change to Security Law#

artcl_ctt: ? Hello and welcome to Biz Today, for this Monday, December 20th.?

? The local stock market started the new week on a bullish note... buoyed by rosy year-end prospects for Wall Street.
? The benchmark KOSPI finished up 17 points... at 967.
In early trade... the index HAD climbed some 30 points... on telecom share rallies.
But profit-takers later ate into some of those gains.
Trading volume and value amounted to 252 million shares and 3-point-8 trillion won, respectively.
Losers, though... doubled the number of winners.
SK Telecom was among the 9 issues soaring to their daily limit highs.
13 hit their limit lows.

Here''s a look at some major stocks.?

? Hello, and welcome to Newsroom Update.

? After 442 years of Portuguese rule, Macau has been handed over to China.
Attending the handover ceremony at midnight last night ... were Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Portuguese President Jorge Sampaio.
Like its larger neighbor Hong Kong, Macau will be governed as a ''Special Administrative Region''... and has been promised a high degree of autonomy.
For the next fifty years, it''ll be governed under the one country, two systems formula.
Beijing appointed a local banker Edmund Ho as the first leader of the S-A-R.
97 percent of Macau''s 430-thousand population is Chinese... and most of them seem to welcome the handover.

? Foreign Ministry officials from Japan and North Korea will meet today in Beijing ... to set an agenda on resuming full-scale talks for normalizing bilateral relations.
It''s the first time the two sides have come together in seven years.
Ahead of the government-level talks... Red Cross delegates met to discuss food aid over the weekend.
Japan suspended food shipments to the famine-stricken North in retaliation for Pyongyang''s test-firing of a ballistic missile last year.
But relations have been warming since a high-profile Japanese delegation visited Pyongyang earlier this month.

? And,
the extreme cold continues for the third day in a row in Korea.
This morning, Seoul recorded a low of minus eleven degrees Celsius... the coldest this season.
Even southern regions, are seeing freezing conditions.
On Cheju Island, major traffic problems are being reported... as the island received some 30 centimeters of snow over the weekend... the heaviest snowfall in years.
A heavy snow warning is also posted for the North Cholla Province.
Weather experts say temperatures should return to the yearly norm by Wednesday.

That''s it for now.
Thanks for watching.?

? For the first time... a Korean company has managed to pave the way for ginseng to be exported to Japan as a health product.
Under the name, "hansamin," shipments are slated to begin next March.
Rah Seungyun reports.

? Currently in Japan, ginseng is defined as a medicinal product... and is only found at about one out of ten pharmacies.
Its price, is about ten times more expensive than in Korea.
But that''s all about to change next year.
?4:56" I first thought of exporting ginseng as I made frequent trips to Japan.  As gifts, I would always bring ginseng, which is known to fight signs of aging and effects of dioxin."
Numerous studies have shown ginseng to be effective in the fight against cancer and even sterility.
That''s why ginseng... the root, itself... and its many  byproducts is the number one item favored by foreign visitors to Korea.
This past July, the Seo Doo Trading Company and the recently privatized Korea Ginseng Cooperative Federation asked the Japanese government... to define ginseng as a health food.
And last month, the Ministry of Health and Welfare finally gave the green light.
?  "Now that Korean Ginseng is being exported to Japan, it will benefit the health of Japanese citizens and hopefully benefit the Korean Ginseng industry."
It was the very first time a Korean company had managed such a feat.
With the signing of the contract... two products, ginseng extract and ginseng drink will be more widely available on the Japanese market... and at about one third of current prices.
?"8:23 We''re planning on selling the products at places crowded with shoppers, such as supermarkets and convenience stores."
?According to a leading Japanese advertising firm Dentsu... the appetite for ginseng in Japan, amounts to one trillion yen ... about 10 billion dollars every ?year.
Korean officials hope to sell some 25-million dollars worth of ginseng products next year.
Rah Seungyun, Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: Insam Export # Exporting Ginseng to Japan #
artcl_titl_en: Insam Export # Exporting Ginseng to Japan #

artcl_ctt:
A BALANCE IN PAY

The government says it wants to raise civil service wages by almost 10% starting next year, to better match the pay levels of private corporations.
-------------------------------
CRIMINAL EXTRADITION TREATY

The Justice Ministry begins compiling names of Koreans avoiding capture in the United States, as an extradition treaty between Seoul and Washington takes effect.
-------------------------------
TOUGHER KOSDAQ MEASURES

Financial authorities say listing requirements for venture firms will become tighter next year, to prevent profiting as soon as the firms are listed on the over-the-counter market.
-------------------------------
DIPLOMATIC POST CHANGES

Seoul''s Foreign Ministry conducts a senior-level reshuffle, appointing new names to posts that include vice minister, and ambassadors to Japan, Russia, and the U.N.

?
?Civil servants could get almost 10% more pay next year... to better match the levels at private corporations.

?The Justice Ministry starts collecting names of Korean criminals hiding out in the U.S... as a bilateral extradition treaty takes effect.

?And over-the-counter listing requirements for venture firms... to get tougher next year... to prevent these companies from turning a quick profit.?

?Welcome to Arirang News.
I''m Ahn Junghyun in Seoul.
?And I''m Hyun Chulho.
Stay with us for the day''s top stories.?

? Time now to quickly flip through today''s local papers...

? First off, a Korean-Japanese business tycoon is coming to Seoul today.
Masa-yashi Sohn... the head of Softbank is expected to set up a holding company in Korea.
Thanks to the internet boom, Softbank recently became Japan''s number five company in terms of market capitalization.
Over the next three years, Sohn says he will invest billions of won in local internet ventures.

And staying with the business world... a major merger of domestic telecommunication companies.
S-K Telecom... which provides mobile phone services on 0-1-1... will take over Shinsege(신세기), or 0-1-7.
S-K will buy shares owned by POSCO and Kolon(코롱)... to grab 57-percent of the market.
Some industry watchers say... the buyout might face anti-trust regulations.

And beer lovers can look forward to a wider range of flavors next year.
Manufacturers are experimenting with new additives... like ginseng, apple and other natural ingredients.
It''s all possible now that regulations concerning beer production have been greatly eased... allowing producers to put out different types of beer.

And we begin our newscast this morning in Macau...?

? Venture capital firms... from next year... will see some tighter restrictions surrounding Korea''s over-the-counter market.
It''s a change to prevent these companies from taking quick profits.
Here are the details.

? Financial authorities unveiled a set of measures aimed at restoring stability and preventing overheating on Korea''s over-the-counter bourse.
Beginning next April... venture capital firms will face tougher regulations... when getting the small and medium-sized businesses that they''ve invested in... listed on the KOSDAQ.
They''ll be required to hold more than a 10 percent stake in the venture companies... for longer than one year.
The tightened listing requirement is to prevent profit-taking by the venture capitals... soon after their companies are listed on the market.
Plus, the regulation on stock distribution will be reinforced... so that a KOSDAQ-listed firm has to have at least 500 minority shareholders, instead of the current 100... who, in turn, have to hold 10 to 30 percent of the company stocks.
The government also decided to strengthen supervision over the KOSDAQ... by beefing up its watchdog staff... from the current 12... to 40.
And to guard against a possible crash... out of the 411 listed firms... 58 with poor business track records... will be delisted in the first half of next year.?
artcl_titl: 벤처투자기업 1년 지나야 코스닥 상장#Tightened Listing Requirement for Venture Companies#
artcl_titl_en: 벤처투자기업 1년 지나야 코스닥 상장#Tightened Listing Requirement for Venture Companies#

artcl_ctt:
? Hong Kong stocks were led higher by a handful of leading blue chips... and the continuing popularity of technology stocks.
The Hang Seng index closed 226 points firmer... at 16-thousand 212.
Despite the strong gain... analysts said the rally was narrowly based... and coincided with a market in which institutions were dwindling and turnover was declining.

Stocks in Australia scrambled back from their early losses... to end virtually unchanged.
The All Ordinaries closed down less than a point... at 31-37.
Traders credit a late rally in resource stocks... for the market''s quick rebound.

And here we have the day''s exchange rates.?
